         <tei:p>Taxonomy of Neotropical Derbidae in<tei:lb/>the new tribe Mysidiini (Homoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Peter S. Broomfield</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 50 No 1 28 February 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History) , instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06008 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol50Nolppl-152<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 28 February 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy of Neotropical Derbidae in the new tribe<tei:lb/>Mysidiini (Homoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Peter S. Broomfield</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Techniques</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derbinae 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to tribes of Derbinae 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidiini trib. n</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of Mysidiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Checklist of Mysidiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia Westwood</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudomysidia Metcalf 77</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia Muir 87</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimiella gen. n 96</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidaloides gen. n 98</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neomysidia gen. n 99</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ipsemysidia gen. n 100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amysidiella gen. n 101</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramysidia gen. n 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Symidia Muir 108</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References Ill</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily Derbinae is divided into two tribes, the Derbini and Mysidiini, the latter newly described.<tei:lb/>Six genera and 136 species are described as new, one subspecies is raised to specific status, four specific<tei:lb/>synonymies and four combinations are newly established, and one neotype and 17 lectotypes are<tei:lb/>designated. Keys to the tribes, 10 genera and 182 species are provided.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Derbidae is one of the largest and least-known families of the Fulgoroidea, with probably<tei:lb/>less than one-fifth of the species currently recognised. It is world- wide in distribution, and the<tei:lb/>majority of the genera and species are confined to the tropics.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The biology of the Derbidae is little known. The adults are phloem feeders, occurring on a<tei:lb/>wide variety of trees and shrubs, in grass land, and occasionally on cultivated cereals. In the<tei:lb/>U.S.A., Dozier (1928) recorded them feeding on numerous species of deciduous trees,<tei:lb/>frequently in moist situations. In the New World tropics they often appear to be randomly<tei:lb/>scattered throughout primary and secondary forest, although individual species may occur in<tei:lb/>very large numbers in plantations. There is little information on their host specificity, and they<tei:lb/>are of no known major economic importance. The nymphal stages, which are almost completely<tei:lb/>unknown, are frequently associated with decaying vegetation, and are often numerous amongst<tei:lb/>the litter of the forest floor or in plantations and orchards. They have been found by the present<tei:lb/>author in old beetle galleries in rotten timber, which suggests that they feed on fungal exudates.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 50 (1): 1-152 Issued 28 February 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>2 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The family-group name Derbidae was first proposed by Schaum (1850), with Derbe Fabricius<tei:lb/>(1803) as the type-genus. The family was divided into the Derbinae and Kermesiinae by<tei:lb/>Kirkaldy (1906), but subsequently the latter subfamily was rendered obsolete when Kermesia<tei:lb/>was shown to be more correctly placed in the Meenoplidae. West wood (1840) divided Derbe<tei:lb/>into seven subgenera: Derbe, Mysidia, Zeugma, Thracia, Phenice, Patara and Cenchrea, all of<tei:lb/>which have subsequently been raised to generic status. In 1900 Kirkaldy proposed the name<tei:lb/>Zoraida as a replacement name for Thracia, the latter being preoccupied. Muir (1913), studying<tei:lb/>the Old World fauna, ignored the subfamilies and divided the family into four 'groups' based on<tei:lb/>tegminal venation. Later (1917) he rearranged these groupings into the subfamilies Derbinae,<tei:lb/>Otiocerinae, Cenchreinae and Rhotaninae, including in the Derbinae the genera Zoraida,<tei:lb/>Zeugma, Mysidia and Sikaiana. In 1918 Muir revised his classification as a result of his study of<tei:lb/>New World material. Still using characters of the wing and tegminal venation, he separated<tei:lb/>Zoraida and related genera into a distinct subfamily, the Zoraidinae, which he divided into the<tei:lb/>tribes Zoraidini and Sikaianini, and relegated the Cenchreinae, Otiocerinae, Derbinae and<tei:lb/>Rhotaninae to tribes within the Derbinae. This arrangement was confirmed in 1930 and was<tei:lb/>subsequently followed by Metcalf (1938). Of Westwood's original seven subgenera of Derbe,<tei:lb/>Muir (1930) assigned Derbe, Mysidia and Zeugma to the Derbini, though he had recognised<tei:lb/>(1913) that, with the inclusion of Zeugma, such a grouping was not a natural one. Metcalf (1938)<tei:lb/>erected Pseudomysidia and included it in the Derbini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This classification was accepted by Metcalf (19456), and revised by Fennah (1952) who, also<tei:lb/>using the venation of the tegmina and wings, omitted the subfamily groupings and divided the<tei:lb/>family directly into the tribes proposed by Muir (1918). Recognising their true affinities he<tei:lb/>transferred Zeugma to the Zoraidini, and Symidia and Dysimia from the Cenchreini to the<tei:lb/>Derbini. However, by ignoring subfamilies this classification restricts the grouping of taxa to<tei:lb/>only two levels below that of family, and does not acknowledge the relationship between the<tei:lb/>Zoraidini and Sikaianini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the present study of the Derbini (sensu Fennah, 1952), the male genitalia have been<tei:lb/>examined in order to evaluate their importance as taxonomic characters in the group; a<tei:lb/>secondary objective was to investigate the generic groupings, and to propose a classification<tei:lb/>whereby the affinities of these genera might be more clearly expressed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Techniques</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters of the head may occasionally be obscured by deposits of white wax, which may be<tei:lb/>removed with a fine paint brush. The measurements in the species descriptions are taken with<tei:lb/>the insect in dorsal aspect; the width includes the eyes, and the length is from the base to the apex<tei:lb/>of the anterior extension. In most cases the vertex and frons merge imperceptibly into each<tei:lb/>other, and the length of the vertex is therefore not included. The length of the frons is assumed to<tei:lb/>be from its base to a point level with the dorsal margins of the eyes. The proportions of the<tei:lb/>thorax, and the presence or absence of carinae on the frontal and dorsal surfaces, are important<tei:lb/>at specific level. These are best observed under incident light at an angle of 45 to the surface<tei:lb/>under examination. The length of the abdomen varies according to the condition of the<tei:lb/>specimen. For this reason 'whole body' measurements are unreliable and are not provided.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pigmentation of the tegmen and wing is frequently faint and occasionally obscured by<tei:lb/>waxy deposits; it is best observed at low magnification in natural light, against a white<tei:lb/>background. Frequently, specimens stored in alcohol rapidly lose all pigmentation. For this<tei:lb/>reason extensive use has been made of characters of the male genitalia, the diagnostic features of<tei:lb/>which are heavily sclerotised and do not require staining.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The method of preparation of the male genitalia is similar to that employed for those in the<tei:lb/>majority of auchenorrhynchous Homoptera. The abdomen is best removed entire at its junction<tei:lb/>with the thorax. After softening in heated 10% KOH, the abdomen is macerated in glacial acetic<tei:lb/>acid, cleared in clove oil, cleaned in alcohol, and examined in glycerine. Usually the characters<tei:lb/>of the aedeagus and parameres may then be observed without further dissection. The aedeagus<tei:lb/>is best examined from several aspects, so that permanent preparations are not recommended;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the lateral aspect is sufficient for examination of the parameres. The female genitalia are not<tei:lb/>used in the present study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The terms used in the text are those commonly employed for the Fulgoroidea and are based<tei:lb/>largely on those of Kramer (1950).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I thank the following individuals for their assistance in making available to me the material upon<tei:lb/>which much of this study is based, for the opportunity to examine type-material and, in many<tei:lb/>cases, for most helpful advice. The institutions are referred to in the text by the abbreviations<tei:lb/>given in parenthesis: Dr N. M011er Andersen, Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen (ZM); Dr P.<tei:lb/>Arnaud and Dr D. Rentz, California Academy of Science, San Francisco (CAS); Dr R. G.<tei:lb/>Fennah, formerly of the Commonwealth Institute of Entomology, London; Dr K. G. A.<tei:lb/>Hamilton, Agriculture Canada, Ottawa (AC); Dr J. P. Kramer, United States National<tei:lb/>Museum, Washington D.C. (USNM); Dr I. Lansbury, University Museum, Oxford (UM); Dr<tei:lb/>P. Lindskog, Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet, Stockholm (NR); Dr J. T. Medler, Bernice P. Bishop<tei:lb/>Museum, Honolulu (BPBM); Dr A. F. Newton, Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard<tei:lb/>(MCZ); Dr L. B. O'Brien, Florida Agricultural &amp; Mechanical University, Tallahassee<tei:lb/>(FAMU); Dr N. D. Penny, Institute Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia, Manaus (INPA); Dr<tei:lb/>R. T. Schuh, American Museum of Natural History, New York (AMNH); Dr C. A. Triplehorn,<tei:lb/>Ohio State University, Columbus (OSU); Dr G. Wallace and Dr G. Ekis, Carnegie Museum,<tei:lb/>Pittsburgh (CM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DERBINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derbini sensu Fennah, 1952: 109.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species of the New World subfamily Derbinae range from the southern Nearctic region to the<tei:lb/>southern temperature zone of the Neotropical region, with the greatest number recorded from<tei:lb/>Central America and tropical South America. They appear to be restricted to moist, frequently<tei:lb/>forested, habitats and are unknown from either mountainous areas, e.g. the High Andes, or<tei:lb/>from the desert area of Mexico and the arid Pacific coastlands of South America.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Throughout the subfamily there appears to be a trend towards smaller size with a correspond-<tei:lb/>ing reduction in the venation of the tegmina and wings, especially in the medial and cubital<tei:lb/>areas. This reduction is paralleled in the Zoraidinae, reaching its fullest extent in the Sikaianini.<tei:lb/>In the Derbinae this tendency is evident by comparison of the tegminal venation of Derbe, in<tei:lb/>which the medial vein has an average of 12 branches, with that of Symidia, in which the medial<tei:lb/>vein has only six branches and the species are among the smallest and most specialised in the<tei:lb/>subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A second , related , tendency paralleled in the rest of the Derbidae is the lateral compression of<tei:lb/>the vertex and frons between the eyes. The extremes of this trend within the Derbinae are shown<tei:lb/>by the relatively broad and parallel-sided configuration of the vertex and frons in Derbe, and the<tei:lb/>strongly compressed condition of these parts in the more specialised genera Symidia, Mysida-<tei:lb/>loides and Paramysidia. A third, independent, trend is the shortening of the frons and clypeus<tei:lb/>with accompanying obsolescence of the longitudinal carinae of the latter, as in Dysimia,<tei:lb/>Mysidaloides and Dysimiella in contrast to Derbe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>While there is little variation in the proportions of the second antennal segment, except for the<tei:lb/>genus Mysidaloides, within the Derbinae, the antennal flagellum tends to migrate from the<tei:lb/>primitive apical position, as in Derbe, to a subapical position as in Mysidia and Neomysidia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia also show several trends in the Derbinae. The shaft of the aedeagus is<tei:lb/>horizontal, basically cylindrical, usually symmetrical and usually with anteriorly directed<tei:lb/>spine-like and/or flap-like processes subapically on the dorsal surface. The ventral surface is<tei:lb/>rarely armed. The paired parameres are large, usually slightly curved, with their apices directed<tei:lb/>medially and their ventral margins closely opposed when at rest. In the frequent absence of an<tei:lb/>extended subgenital plate, the parameres are presumed to shield the aedeagus ventrally and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>4 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>posteriorly, while dorsal protection is commonly provided by the posterior extension of the hind<tei:lb/>margin of the anal tube.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The trends within the male genitalia are complex, though often correlated with reduction of<tei:lb/>the tegmina and constriction of the head. From a comparison with other families of auchenor-<tei:lb/>rhynchous Homoptera, e.g., Membracidae and Cicadellidae, it is assumed that the heavily<tei:lb/>armed aedeagus bearing simple, paired, spine-like processes on the dorsal surface only, with the<tei:lb/>ventral surface unarmed, and with the grasping function of the parameres little developed, is the<tei:lb/>more primitive condition. This condition is seen in Derbe, in which there is also a small degree of<tei:lb/>asymmetry, and other genera such as Pseudomysidia (Figs 34-80). The tendency for the<tei:lb/>reduction of the dorsal spine-like processes of the aedeagus, or their replacement completely or<tei:lb/>partially by flap-like processes, the occasional development of one or more ventral processes,<tei:lb/>and an accompanying development of the dorsal process of the paramere, are seen in Mysidia<tei:lb/>and reach the extreme degree in Dysimia (Figs 94-129). A secondary modification occurs in<tei:lb/>Paramysidia, Ipsemysidia and Amysidiella in which the dorsal process of the paramere is<tei:lb/>frequently obsolete or absent and is often replaced by a small, hook-like, subbasal secondary<tei:lb/>process accompanied occasionally (Paramysidia) by pronounced asymmetry of the aedeagus. A<tei:lb/>separate tendency is seen in Derbe in which the aedeagus is heavily armed and the often very<tei:lb/>complex parameres show a variety of forms consistent with a grasping function during<tei:lb/>copulation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relatively primitive characters of Derbe, as seen in the tegminal and wing venation, the<tei:lb/>proportions of the head, and the distinctly different developmental trends in the male genitalia,<tei:lb/>set it sufficiently apart from other genera of Derbini (sensu Fennah, 1952) to divide the tribe into<tei:lb/>two groups. This necessitates the elevation of all the tribes recognised by Fennah, except<tei:lb/>Sikaianini, to subfamily rank, thereby permitting the division of Derbinae (Derbini sensu<tei:lb/>Fennah, 1952) into Derbini (type-genus Derbe) and Mysidiini (type-genus Mysidia). This action<tei:lb/>also illustrates the close relationship between the Zoraidini and the Sikaianini which remain as<tei:lb/>tribes within the Zoraidinae, as proposed by Muir (1918). The proposed classification of the<tei:lb/>Derbidae is as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derbidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derbinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Derbini New World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidiini New World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Otiocerinae New and Old World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cenchreinae New and Old World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhotaninae Old World<tei:lb/>Zoraidinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoraidini Old World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sikaianini New and Old World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to tribes of Derbinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Head with junction of frons and vertex marked by a distinct transverse carina. Tegmen with</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20-23 branches of veins extending to posterior and apical margins; medial vein with basal fork<tei:lb/>not less than 6-branched; cubital vein with 4-6 branches. All branches of medial and cubital<tei:lb/>veins linked by a continuous oblique band of cross-veins. Wing with subcostal and radial veins<tei:lb/>fused over c. basal one-third length; total number of branches of medial and cubital veins<tei:lb/>attaining posterior and apical margins from 6-1 (Fig . 1 ) DERBINI Schaum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Head with frons and vertex merging imperceptibly, lacking a transverse carina. Tegmen with</tei:p>
         <tei:p>never more than 16 branches of veins extending to posterior and apical margins (Pseudomysi-<tei:lb/>dia), commonly with 11-13; medial vein with basal fork not more than 3-branched; cubital<tei:lb/>vein never with more than 4 branches. Cross-veins of medial and cubital areas not as above.<tei:lb/>Wing with subcostal vein obsolete; total number of branches of medial and cubital veins<tei:lb/>attaining posterior and apical margins not exceeding 5 (Figs 2-11) MYSIDIINI trib. n. (p. 5)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Derbini is monotypic, the genus Derbe consisting of 16 species confined to Central America<tei:lb/>and northern South America.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Mysidiini is erected to accommodate all the genera of Derbinae except Derbe, i.e.,<tei:lb/>Mysidia, Pseudomysidia, Dysimia and Symidia, and the newly described Amysidiella, Ipsemysi-<tei:lb/>dia, Mysidaloides, Neomysidia, Paramysidia and Dysimiella. Species of the tribe extend from<tei:lb/>the southern U.S.A. to Uruguay, with the majority occurring in tropical Central and South<tei:lb/>America. Only one species of Mysidia and eight species of Dysimia have been recorded from the<tei:lb/>Caribbean Islands, excluding Trinidad. One Dysimia and one Paramysidia species are known<tei:lb/>from the U.S.A. ; the former appears to have reached south-eastern U.S. A. by 'island hopping'<tei:lb/>across the Caribbean, while the latter probably first became established in Texas after dispersing<tei:lb/>through Central America.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MYSIDIINI trib. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-genus: Mysidia Westwood, 1840: 83.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertex extending not more than one-half of its length beyond eyes, junction with frons not marked by a<tei:lb/>transverse carina. Frons longer than wide; lateral margins apically subparallel, diverging subbasally.<tei:lb/>Pronotum longitudinally constricted at mid-dorsal line, not less than 6 times as wide as long. Tegmen<tei:lb/>2-0-3-0 times as long as wide; radial and subcostal veins fused subbasally, combined radial, medial and<tei:lb/>cubital veins with not more than 16 branches. Wing with subcostal vein obsolete; combined radial, medial<tei:lb/>and cubital veins with not more than six branches.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The head in dorsal aspect is distinctly broader than long, its width across the eyes being between<tei:lb/>one and three-fourths greater than its length from the base to the apparent apex of the vertex.<tei:lb/>The vertex usually extends beyond the eyes for up to one-half its length except in Mysidaloides,<tei:lb/>in which it terminates approximately level with the anterior margins of the eyes, due to the<tei:lb/>exceptionally large size of the eyes. The junction of the vertex and frons is smoothly, regularly,<tei:lb/>and obtusely rounded, except in one species of Dysimia where it is subacute. The transverse<tei:lb/>carina present in Derbe is absent in the Mysidiini. The basal margin of the vertex is usually<tei:lb/>transverse, but in Dysimia, Symidia, and Dysimiella, and to a lesser extent in Ipsemysidia and<tei:lb/>Paramysidia, it is broadly and deeply incised medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The frons is laterally constricted and is usually from three to seven times as long as its apical<tei:lb/>width. In Symidia and Pseudomysidia its length may be up to 20 times its apical width. The ratio<tei:lb/>between the length and width of the frons is important at specific and sometimes also generic<tei:lb/>level. In all genera, with the exception of Symidia and Pseudomysidia, the lateral margins of the<tei:lb/>frons are strongly divergent from the level of the ventral margins of the eyes to the junction with<tei:lb/>the clypeus; the degree and regularity of this divergence are also important at generic level. The<tei:lb/>width of the frons at its junction with the clypeus is much greater than its apical width, varying<tei:lb/>between one-fourth (Pseudomysidia} of to approximately equal to its length (Dysimiella and<tei:lb/>Neomysidia), with the other genera occurring between these extremes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genae are broadly rounded in lateral aspect, with the exception of a single Dysimia<tei:lb/>species (see above), and extend anteriorly beyond the eyes from one-third to one-half the<tei:lb/>horizontal diameter of the eye. In Mysidaloides, due to the very large size of the eyes, this<tei:lb/>anterior extension is minimal. The eyes are large and reniform, with the ventral surfaces<tei:lb/>adjacent to the antennae weakly concave, except in Mysidaloides where they are hemispherical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second antennal segment is club-shaped, approximately one and one-half times as long as<tei:lb/>its maximum breadth, except in Mysidaloides in which the length is five times the maximum<tei:lb/>breadth. In the primitive condition, seen in Symidia, Dysimia, Pseudomysidia, and Dysimiella,<tei:lb/>the antennal flagellum arises apically from a truncate second segment. In Mysida, Mysidaloides,<tei:lb/>Amysidiella, Paramysidia, Ipsemysidia, and Neomysidia the flagellum has assumed a subapical<tei:lb/>position, and the apex of the segment is narrowly rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ocelli are commonly distinct and only rarely obscure or obsolete. They are small in<tei:lb/>Dysimia, Symidia, Mysidaloides, Ipsemysidia and Amysidiella, variable in size in Mysidia,<tei:lb/>Pseudomysidia and Dysimiella, are very large and prominent in Paramysidia and Neomysidia;<tei:lb/>they are of diagnostic value at species level in Mysidia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the majority of genera the clypeus is approximately as long as the frons (the term 'clypeus'<tei:lb/>being used throughout the text to denote the combined para- and ante-clypeus); in Dysimiella,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>O PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>however, it is somewhat shorter than the frons, and in Pseudomysidia it is up to one-third longer.<tei:lb/>Slight variation in the length of the clypeus is of specific diagnostic value in many instances. In<tei:lb/>the primitive condition the clypeus bears distinct and percurrent medial and lateral longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae, as seen in Symidia and Pseudomysidia, and occasionally in Mysidia; these are obsolete<tei:lb/>or absent in the remaining genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The rostrum in the primitive condition extends to the apex of the abdomen, as seen in<tei:lb/>Pseudomysidia and Symidia. In the majority of genera it terminates approximately level with the<tei:lb/>hind coxae, except in Mysidia where its length is extremely variable and is of value in specific<tei:lb/>diagnosis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pronotum is longitudinally constricted at the mid-dorsal line, with the posterior margin<tei:lb/>very broadly and deeply incised. In Mysidia, Paramysidia, Mysidaloides, Dysimiella, Neomysi-<tei:lb/>dia, Ipsemysidia and Amysidiella, its maximum width is usually 10-20 times its medial length,<tei:lb/>though in some species of Mysidia it may be so strongly constricted that the width is up to 50<tei:lb/>times the medial length. In Pseudomysidia, Symidia, and Dysimia this constriction is relatively<tei:lb/>slight, and the width of the pronotum may be as little as 6-8 times its length. The ratio of the<tei:lb/>length to the breadth of the pronotum varies greatly between species, especially in Mysidia, and<tei:lb/>is often of considerable diagnostic value.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fronto-lateral surfaces of the pronotum may be distinctly carinate in all genera, though<tei:lb/>they are not consistently so in Mysidia and Pseudomysidia; in which genera their presence or<tei:lb/>absence is of great diagnostic value at species level. In Symidia these carinae are greatly elevated<tei:lb/>and foliaceous, and continue along the lateral and ventral margins to form pronounced antennal<tei:lb/>foveae; which, although occurring intermittently in other subfamilies of the Derbidiae, are<tei:lb/>otherwise absent in the Derbinae. The tegulae also vary in the possession of carinae, these being<tei:lb/>sometimes present in Mysidia, Pseudomysidia, and Dysimia, although absent in the other<tei:lb/>genera. The presence or absence of these carinae may be of value at specific level. Both the disc<tei:lb/>of the mesonotum and the scutellum are approximately as wide as long, their proportions<tei:lb/>varying little between genera; the former occasionally bears three distinct longitudinal carinae,<tei:lb/>but these are more usually obsolete or absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tegmen is from two and one-half to three times as long as its maximum breadth (slightly<tei:lb/>broader in Dysimiella) with the radial and sub-costal veins fused over their basal one-third to<tei:lb/>one-half length. The radial and medial veins are distinct from near their base in Mysidia,<tei:lb/>Paramysidia, Ipsemysidia, Pseudomysidia, and Mysidaloides, but in Symidia, Dysimiella,<tei:lb/>Dysimia, Neomysidia, and Amysidiella they may be fused for up to one-quarter of their length.<tei:lb/>The radial vein is usually two branched, although three branches are present in Symidia, which<tei:lb/>also has the usual seven branches of the medial vein reduced to six. The medial vein of<tei:lb/>Pseudomysidia is eleven-branched, a condition unique in the tribe and considered to represent a<tei:lb/>primitive condition. The number of branches of the cubital vein also varies. The genera Mysidia,<tei:lb/>Paramysidia, Mysidaloides, Dysimiella, Neomysidia, Ipsemysidia, and Amysidiella have four<tei:lb/>branches; Pseudomysidia and Dysimia have three; and Symidia, perhaps due to the small size of<tei:lb/>the insects, only two. The total number of branches of the radial, medial and cubital veins is<tei:lb/>therefore usually thirteen, the exceptions being Pseudomysidia with sixteen, Dysimia with<tei:lb/>twelve, and Symidia with eleven. In the Derbini the total varies from twenty to twenty-three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The wing is usually approximately one-half the length of the tegmen, but is somewhat longer<tei:lb/>in Dysimiella and Paramysidia, and occasionally longer in Mysidia. The subcostal vein is fused<tei:lb/>throughout its length with the radial vein, in contrast with the Derbini where it is distinct for the<tei:lb/>greater part of its length. The radial vein is also unbranched. The number of branches of the<tei:lb/>medial vein is variable; being two in the majority of genera, three in Pseudomysidia; in Dysimia,<tei:lb/>Symidia, and Dysimiella it is unbranched. The cubital vein has either two branches, as in<tei:lb/>Pseudomysidia, Neomysidia and Symidia, or three, as in Amysidiella, Ipsemysidia, Mysidia,<tei:lb/>Mysidaloides, Paramysidia, Dysimia, and Dysimiella. The total number of branches of the<tei:lb/>medial and cubital veins therefore varies from three to five, contrasting with the total of six to ten<tei:lb/>in the Derbini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The head and body are usually pale yellowish brown, rarely dark brown, with brown, black or<tei:lb/>red markings frequently present, particularly on the head and the frontolateral surfaces of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pronotum. The tegmina and wings are usually predominently whitish hyaline but may also be<tei:lb/>clear, yellowish or smoky brown throughout in some species of Mysidia. They are frequently<tei:lb/>marked with darker spots or transverse bands or with the veins and cross veins dark margined.<tei:lb/>All markings are consistent within species and are of diagnostic value at this level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia are extremely variable in the shape of the aedeagus and parameres, with a<tei:lb/>distinct correlation in many cases between a reduction in the processes of the former and an<tei:lb/>increase in those of the latter. This correlation is well illustrated within Dysimia, where in the<tei:lb/>species numa Fennah the dorsal process of the paramere is but little developed while the<tei:lb/>aedeagus is the most highly armed in the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Both the aedeagus and the parameres are of very great diagnostic importance at specific level,<tei:lb/>especially in the case of externally similar forms, and occasionally at generic level, i.e.<tei:lb/>Paramysidia. The primitive condition appears to be that in which the shaft of the aedeagus is<tei:lb/>armed subapically with simple, paired, symmetrically arranged, spine-like processes on the<tei:lb/>dorsal surface only, as in Pseudomysidia, Amysidiella, and a few species of Mysidia. The<tei:lb/>development of additional flap-like processes occurs in Paramysidia, Dysimia, Symidia, Mysi-<tei:lb/>daloides, Dysimiella, Ipsemysidia, and most species of Mysidia. The possession of flap-like<tei:lb/>processes only, as seen in Neomysidia and some species of Mysidia, is regarded as being a further<tei:lb/>development which reaches its most advanced condition in certain species of Dysimia, where the<tei:lb/>grasping function of the aedeagal processes can only be minimal and the parameres appear to<tei:lb/>have assumed this task during copulation. The ventral surface of the aedeagus is usually<tei:lb/>unarmed, the exceptions being Ipsemysidia and a few species of Mysidia. The development of<tei:lb/>asymmetry in the aedeagal processes, present in Symidia and occasionally in Mysidia, reaches its<tei:lb/>greatest extent in Paramysidia, where an unpaired medial dorsal process is also present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The dorsal process of the paramere is well developed in Mysidaloides and Dysimiella, and in<tei:lb/>the majority of species of Mysidia and Dysimia. It is less developed in Pseudomysidia and<tei:lb/>Symidia, and greatly reduced in Amysidiella, Ipsemysidia, Neomysidia, and Paramysidia, and in<tei:lb/>some species of Mysidia and Dysimia. The reduction, or loss, of the dorsal process is often<tei:lb/>compensated for by the development of a small hook-like secondary process subbasally . Only in<tei:lb/>Mysidia is there the occasional development of an additional process on the ventral surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male subgenital plate is usually short with its posterior margin transverse; only in<tei:lb/>Dysimiella is it strongly produced medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genitalia appear not to be of taxonomic value at either the generic or specific level,<tei:lb/>with the possible exception of the subgenital plate. The variation in this character is however too<tei:lb/>slight to be of use diagnostically .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of Mysidiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Medial vein of tegmen with 11 branches extending to posterior and apical margins (Fig. 11)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Checklist of Mysidiini</tei:p>

         <tei:p>pallida (Fabricius)<tei:lb/>panamensis sp. n.<tei:lb/>peregrina sp. n.<tei:lb/>persephone sp. n.<tei:lb/>perspicua sp. n.<tei:lb/>polyhymnia sp. n.<tei:lb/>pseudocostata sp. n.<tei:lb/>pseudoerecta sp. n.<tei:lb/>pseudonebulosa Muir<tei:lb/>pulchella sp. n.<tei:lb/>punctifera Metcalf<tei:lb/>punctum (Fabricius)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>SYMWIA Muir<tei:lb/>bucaya sp. n.<tei:lb/>/Java Muir<tei:lb/>pintosamia sp. n.<tei:lb/>pseudoffava sp. n.<tei:lb/>withycombei sp . n .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DFSIM/A Muir<tei:lb/>astarte sp. n.<tei:lb/>distincta sp. n.<tei:lb/>fennahisp. n.<tei:lb/>fuscoclypeata Fennah<tei:lb/>jamaicensis (Distant) comb. n.<tei:lb/>maculata Muir</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MYSIDIA Westwood<tei:lb/>Mysidia Westwood, 1840: 83. Type-species: Derbe pallida Fabricius, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head in dorsal aspect usually from one-quarter to one-half greater than length, rarely more or<tei:lb/>less. Vertex extending anterior to eyes for between one-third and one-half its length; lateral margins not</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>10 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>highly elevated, strongly converging from base to level of midline of eyes, thence subparallel to apex; base<tei:lb/>shallowly concave. Frons with lateral margins gradually diverging from apex to base; slender, length<tei:lb/>usually 4-7 times width at apex, 2-0-3-5 times width at base, seldom more or less; junction with vertex<tei:lb/>broadly rounded, indistinct, lacking a transverse carina; lateral carinae very prominent, often semifoli-<tei:lb/>naceus. Genae extending anterior to eyes for one-third to one-half horizontal diameter of eye. Eye weakly<tei:lb/>reniform, ventral margin adjacent to antennal base weakly concave. Antenna with second segment<tei:lb/>club-shaped, apex narrowly rounded; length usually 1-5-2-5 times maximum width; flagellum arising<tei:lb/>subapically. Ocelli commonly distinct, often small, rarely obscure or obsolete, occasionally very large and<tei:lb/>prominent. Clypeus broad, not greatly swollen; commonly as long as, or rather longer than, frons; medial<tei:lb/>carina frequently obsolete or extending only over c. apical one-half length or less, seldom distinct or<tei:lb/>percurrent; lateral carinae commonly not extending over more than basal one-third length, rarely either<tei:lb/>obsolete or distinct throughout. Rostrum often extending to, or beyond, base of subgenital plate; but<tei:lb/>frequently terminating at level of hind coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface of pronotum very deeply and broadly constricted at midline; width usually 10-20 times<tei:lb/>mid-dorsal length, occasionally much greater. Pronto-lateral surfaces often each with a single prominent<tei:lb/>carina curving horizontally from adjacent to midline of eye to lateral margin. Tegulae occasionally each<tei:lb/>with a single horizontal carina. Disc of mesonotum often slightly wider than length at midline; medial and<tei:lb/>two lateral longitudinal carinae rarely distinct and percurrent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen usually 6-12 mm long, rarely distinctly shorter or longer; that of the female usually being up to<tei:lb/>30 per cent longer than that of the male; length c. 3 times maximum breadth. Medial vein distinct from near<tei:lb/>base; subcostal and radial veins fused over c. one-third length from base. Radial vein with two branches<tei:lb/>extending to apical margin; linked to medial vein by a cross-vein at c. two-thirds length, and by another<tei:lb/>adjacent to apical fork. Medial vein forking at c. two-fifths length, and again at midlength; with seven<tei:lb/>branches extending to apical and posterior margins, second and third, and fourth fifth, linked by<tei:lb/>cross-veins. Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin, first linked to apex of clavus<tei:lb/>and to second, third to fourth, and fourth to first branch of medial vein by cross-veins (Fig. 7).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing with length c. one-half to two-thirds that of tegmen. Radial and sub-costal veins fused over rather<tei:lb/>less than basal half of length, unbranched; the former linked to medial vein by a cross-vein at c. two-thirds<tei:lb/>length. Medial vein with two branches extending to apical margin, linked to cubital vein by a single<tei:lb/>cross-vein at c. midlength. Cubital vein with three branches extending to posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body usually pale yellowish brown, seldom dark, often with distinct markings. Tegmen and<tei:lb/>wing often hyaline or whitish hyaline, occasionally deep fuscous, frequently with veins and cross-veins<tei:lb/>broadly margined smoky brown, often with distinct transverse bands or with apical and posterior margins<tei:lb/>smoky brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, basically cylindrical, usually symmetrical, usually<tei:lb/>slender in lateral aspect, often broadly expanded subapically in vertical aspect. Dorsal surface subapically<tei:lb/>usually with one or two, rarely three or four, pairs of spine or flap-like processes occasionally extending<tei:lb/>over lateral surfaces. Lateral and ventral surfaces usually unarmed. Paramere often slender basally,<tei:lb/>frequently obtusely rounded apically; dorsal surface usually with a well-developed posteriorly produced<tei:lb/>process bearing opposed projections on its posterior surface; often with a distinct secondary process. Anal<tei:lb/>tube often very strongly produced and decurved posteriorly, apex often deeply notched at midline.<tei:lb/>Subgenital segment with lateral and ventral margins occasionally bearing distinct, posteriorly directed<tei:lb/>processes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female with posterior margin of subgenital plate commonly transverse or broadly rounded, rarely<tei:lb/>strongly produced or shallowly notched medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia was erected by Westwood (1840) as a subgenus of Derbe to accommodate the Fabrician species<tei:lb/>pallida, squamigera, costata, punctum, testacea and nivea, and his own new species albipennis, lactiflora<tei:lb/>and subfasciata; further species were added by various authors, mainly Metcalf, Fowler, Distant, Walker,<tei:lb/>Muir and, more recently, Fennah, bringing the total number to 34.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As a result of the present study the distribution includes Brazil (69 species), Trinidad (7), Surinam (5),<tei:lb/>Guyana (15), French Guiana (2), Venezuela (4), Colombia (10), Ecuador (11), Bolivia (10), Peru (11),<tei:lb/>Uruguay (1?), Panama (20), Costa Rica (2), Honduras (4), Belize (2), Guatemala (4), Mexico (2) and<tei:lb/>Jamaica (1 species).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The localities from which species are recorded more probably reflects, at least in northern South<tei:lb/>America, intensity of collecting rather than diversity of species; with the exception of Trinidad, Jamaica is<tei:lb/>the only Caribbean island from which the genus is recorded. Due to the previous confusion and frequent<tei:lb/>misidentification, most of the published locality data recorded by Metcalf (1945-6) must be regarded as<tei:lb/>suspect.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Mysidia (based on external characters)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It has not been possible to examine the type-material of stigma, while the unique holotypes of cinerea,<tei:lb/>pallida and pseudonebulosa are badly damaged; these species are therefore omitted from this key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Though external characters are consistent within species, between species they are occasionally slight; in<tei:lb/>these instances reference should be made to the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Key to species of Mysidia (based on male genitalia)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It has not been possible to examine the male genitalia of the following species, which are therefore omitted<tei:lb/>from this key: immaculata, lactiftora, maculicosta, punctifera, quadrifasciata, squamigera, stigma, sub fas-<tei:lb/>data and subfusca. The genitalia of robusta are damaged, and this species is also omitted.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Mysidia asinella sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female: head 0-97 mm long, 1-12 mm wide; pronotum 2-52 mm wide; legmen 12-00-12-50 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>7-05 mm long. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 5 times width at apex, c. 2-5 times width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus c. as long as<tei:lb/>frons; rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Pronotal width 18 times mid-dorsal<tei:lb/>length; fronto-lateral surfaces weakly carinate; tegula not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head bright scarlet, antenna yellow. Pronotum with mid-dorsal and fronto-lateral surfaces scarlet;<tei:lb/>scutellum scarlet; disc of mesonotum brown; abdomen brownish dorsally, tinged scarlet apically. Tegmen<tei:lb/>and wing dark brownish, veins brown, posterior margins very narrowly scarlet. Tegmen unmarked, base<tei:lb/>narrowly scarlet; costal vein and branches, and apical part of subcostal vein and its branches reddish;<tei:lb/>radial-subcostal cross-vein, medial-radial apical cross-vein, and bases of fifth and sixth branches of medial<tei:lb/>vein white. Wing with a narrow, oblique, transverse, whitish band extending from costal to posterior<tei:lb/>margins immediately distad of radial-medial cross-vein; otherwise unmarked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Brazil: Belem, Para, vi.1924 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes, Brazil: 4 $ , Breves, Lower Amazon (INPA; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the absence of males, asinella is readily distinguished by the bright scarlet pigmentation of the<tei:lb/>head and thorax, and by the single pale band on the otherwise dark brownish wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia adusta sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 217, 328, 437)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-67 mm long, 1-03 mm wide; pronotum 2-37 mm wide; tegmen 9-80 mm long; wing 5-90 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female: tegmen 11-70 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 4-5 times width at apex, c. 3 times width at base; ocelli large, prominent; clypeus as<tei:lb/>long as frons; rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Pronotal width 14 times length at<tei:lb/>mid-dorsal line; fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head, excluding antenna, rostrum, and extreme baso-ventral margins usually scarlet; ocelli concol-<tei:lb/>orous. Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a broad, scarlet band extending horizontally from<tei:lb/>adjacent to dorsal margin of eye to lateral margin; tegula and disc of mesonotum pale brownish; scutellum<tei:lb/>irregularly tinged dull pink. Tegmen and wing dark smoky brown; veins and cross-veins dark brown;<tei:lb/>lacking prominent markings. Tegmen with veins over basal third narrowly edged yellowish hyaline; apical<tei:lb/>forks of medial vein, second radial-medial cross- vein, and radial-subcostal cross-vein white; costal and<tei:lb/>posterior marginal veins very narrowly crimson. Wing unmarked; posterior marginal vein narrowly<tei:lb/>crimson.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus broad ; apex with a pair of opposed , flap-like processes extending from ventral surface ;<tei:lb/>dorso-lateral surfaces subapically each with a long, slender, spine-like process; ventral surface subapically<tei:lb/>with two pairs of small, transversally aligned spines. Paramere with apex very broadly rounded; dorsal<tei:lb/>process situated at three-quarters length, large, strongly produced posteriorly. Subgenital plate produced<tei:lb/>medially into a rounded, posteriorly directed, lobe bearing a fringe of long, erect, spine-like hairs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cT, Brazil: Amazonas, 120 km E. of Tapuruquara, 19.L1978 (Penny) (INPA).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Brazil: 1 $, Amazonas, Manaus (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. adusta is readily distinguished by the pigmentation of the head and thorax, and the dark<tei:lb/>brown tegmen and wing, both lacking transverse markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia polyhymnia sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 196, 306, 415)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-61 mm long, 0-86 mm wide; pronotum 1-97 mm wide; tegmen 9-00 mm long; wing 5-10 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 5 times width at apex, 2-33 times width at base; ocelli small, not prominent; clypeus c.<tei:lb/>0-33 longer than frons; rostrum extending to base of subgenital plate. Pronotal width c. 13 times mid-dorsal<tei:lb/>length, fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula distinctly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum dorsal to upper margins of eyes brownish; tegula dark brown; dorsal<tei:lb/>surface of abdomen tinged red basally . Tegmen and wing smoky brownish, veins dark brown. Tegmen with<tei:lb/>cross-veins pale, apical fork of medial vein surrounded by a very small white spot, costal margin basally<tei:lb/>dark brown. Wing unmarked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender in lateral aspect, greatly expanded laterally; dorsal surface at approximately<tei:lb/>two-thirds length with a pair of large processes, each terminating posteriorly in a long, slender, curving<tei:lb/>spine, and anteriorly in a shorter, straighter spine. Paramere very robust; apex very obtusely rounded,<tei:lb/>almost truncate; dorsal process situated at three-fifths length, reduced, proximal component slender,<tei:lb/>inclined antero-dorsally and terminating in a medially directed hook, distal component short and rounded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Brazil: Amazon, Fonteboa (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pigmentation of the tegmen and wing is closely similar to that of caliginosa and inquinata,<tei:lb/>but polyhymnia is distinguished by its larger size, relatively obscure ocelli, carinate tegula, and<tei:lb/>by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia caliginosa Walker<tei:lb/>(Figs 236, 348, 456, 463)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia caliginosa Walker, 1858: 98. Holotype $, BRAZIL (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Mysidia rubra Metcalf, 1945: 128. Holotype cT, GUYANA (AMNH) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-60 mm long, 0-80 mm wide; pronotum 1-60 mm wide; tegmen 7-00-7-65 mm long; wing 4 -50<tei:lb/>mm long. Female: tegmen 7-20-9-80 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 5 times width at apex, 2-5 times width at base; ocelli very large and prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>slightly longer than frons; rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Pronotal width from<tei:lb/>10-12 times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula with carinae weak or obsolete.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>24 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frons and genae dorsally scarlet; ocelli yellow, broadly edged scarlet. Dorsal surfaces of thorax and<tei:lb/>abdomen from pale brown to deep reddish brown, usually scarlet, abdomen rarely blackish; tegula with<tei:lb/>dorsal margin broadly dark brown. Tegmen and wing dark brownish, unmarked; veins and cross-veins<tei:lb/>dark brown; posterior marginal veins very narrowly crimson. Tegmen with costal, subcostal and radial<tei:lb/>veins frequently tinged crimson.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus cylindrical; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large, flap-like processes, each<tei:lb/>terminating in a slender, curving spine; lateral surfaces each with four slender spine-like processes.<tei:lb/>Paramere slender; apex narrowly rounded; dorsal process well developed, situated somewhat distad of<tei:lb/>mid-length, apex weakly produced posteriorly; dorsal surface subasally with a group of short robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ (caliginosa), Brazil: Santarem (Bates) (BMNH). Holotype cf (rubrd), Guyana: Kartabo,<tei:lb/>Bartica District, 1920 (AMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guyana: 1 CT, 2 $ (BMNH). Brazil: 1 $, Santarem (Bates) (BMNH); 2 $ (BMNH). Bolivia: 1 cf<tei:lb/>(BMNH). Colombia: 1 $ (BMNH). Ecuador: 2 cf , 2 $ (BMNH). Panama: 1 cf (FAMU). Peru: 1 cf<tei:lb/>(FAMU). Surinam: 1 (FAMU). Trinidad: 1 $ (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of rubra Metcalf has the tegmina and wings damaged or missing; the genitalia are<tei:lb/>preserved in balsam and are not accessible for detailed study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the dark brown, unmarked, tegmen and wing, the<tei:lb/>pigmentation of the head and body, and by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia inquinata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 243, 354, 464)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-62 mm long, 0-67 mm wide; pronotum 1-47 mm wide; tegmen 7-22-7-25 mm long; wing4-34<tei:lb/>mm long. Female: tegmen 8-70 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 6 times width at apex, c. 3 times width at base; ocelli very large and prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>slightly longer than frons; rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Pronotal width 14<tei:lb/>times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula with carinae weak or obsolete.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frons and genae anterior to eyes usually tinged deep crimson; lateral surfaces of clypeus weakly tinged<tei:lb/>crimson. Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum dorsad to level of eyes often suffused reddish; tegula reddish,<tei:lb/>dorsal margins dark reddish brown; disc of mesonotum reddish brown; dorsal surface of abdomen<tei:lb/>occasionally dark brown. Tegmen and wing uniformly dark brownish, unmarked; veins and cross- veins<tei:lb/>dark brown; posterior margins often very narrowly crimson. Tegmen with apical branches of subcostal and<tei:lb/>radial veins bright crimson or white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus cylindrical; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large, flap-like processes, each<tei:lb/>bearing a long spine subbasally on dorsal surface, and numerous very small and blunt spines on internal and<tei:lb/>ventral surfaces; lateral surfaces each with a long, apically serrated, process subapically. Paramere slender;<tei:lb/>apex broadly rounded; dorsal process situated at three-fifths length, apex strongly produced posteriorly;<tei:lb/>dorsal surface at one-quarter length with a rounded, internally directed secondary process bearing<tei:lb/>numerous short, robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Brazil: Amazon, Fonteboa (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Brazil: 14 cf, 11 $, Amazonas (BMNH; INPA).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tegminal and wing pigmentation of inquinata is very similar to that of caliginosa and<tei:lb/>polyhymnia, but it differs from the former in the proportions and pigmentation of the head and<tei:lb/>pronotum, and from the latter by its much smaller size, and from both in the structure of the<tei:lb/>male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia venusta sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 183, 293, 402)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-55 mm long, 0-69 mm wide; pronotum 1-47 mm wide; tegmen 6-20 mm long; wing 3-40 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 4 times width at apex, 2-66 times width at base; ocelli small, indistinct; clypeus as long as<tei:lb/>frons; rostrum extending to posterior surface of hind coxae. Pronotal width slightly less than 12 times<tei:lb/>length at mid-dorsal line; fronto-lateral carinae prominent; tegula not carinate.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 25</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body unmarked . Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline ; veins pale yellow , otherwise totally devoid<tei:lb/>of pigmentation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus basally slender, broadly expanded subapically; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of<tei:lb/>large, apically shallowly bifurcate processes; a pair of rounded, flap-like processes; at midline, a single,<tei:lb/>apically shallowly concave, flap-like process. Paramere with ventral margin somewhat dorsally produced<tei:lb/>apically; dorsal process very reduced, situated at approximately midlength, not at all produced dorsally or<tei:lb/>posteriorly; dorsal surface at one-third length with a simple hook-like process, basally with a rounded lobe<tei:lb/>bearing numerous robust spines; ventral surface basally produced into a small rounded lobe bearing<tei:lb/>numerous robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Brazil: Amazon, Rio Autaz, x (Roman) (NR).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia bear a close resemblance to those of cheesemani, but venusta is readily<tei:lb/>distinguished by the complete absence of tegminal and wing pigmentation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia richardsisp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Male: head 0-73 mm long, 0-90 mm wide; pronotum 2-10 mm wide; tegmen 8.92 mm long; wing 5-20 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Head and body unmarked. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline, veins and cross-veins pale brownish<tei:lb/>yellow. Tegmen with costal cell pale smoky yellow; posterior margin very pale yellowish brown. Wing with<tei:lb/>posterior margin very narrowly and faintly yellowish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus with dorsal surface subapically bearing a pair of large flap-like lobes extending<tei:lb/>anteriorly to midlength, each with a small lateral spine at c. midlength; ventral surface at midlength with an<tei:lb/>antero-ventrally directed, apically rounded process at each lateral angle. Paramere slender, apex narrowly<tei:lb/>rounded; dorsal process situated slightly basad of midlength, posteriorly produced, with a large, rounded,<tei:lb/>medially directed process on internal surface at three-quarters length.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>This species is distinguished by the lack of distinct markings on the head, body, tegmen and<tei:lb/>wing, and by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia Hmpida sp. n.</tei:p>

Paramere robust, apex irregularly rounded; dorsal process situated somewhat<tei:lb/>distad of midlength, small, apex not produced posteriorly.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Mysidia robusta sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus very broad in dorsal aspect; apex recurving; lateral surfaces each with a very large,<tei:lb/>flap-like process extending over dorsal surface and overlapping at midline, each with anterior margin<tei:lb/>produced dorsally into a slender secondary process with apical angles produced into acute spines.<tei:lb/>Paramere very robust, broadly rounded, apex obtuse; dorsal margin strongly curved medially and<tei:lb/>ventrally, considerably expanded from mid-length to apex; dorsal process very small, situated at two-fifths<tei:lb/>length, apex not produced.</tei:p>

Pronotal width 17 times<tei:lb/>mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula prominently carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surfaces of head and thorax brownish; genae adjacent to eyes and fronto-lateral surfaces of<tei:lb/>pronotum at level of eyes reddish; abdomen dorsally with a small red spot on either side of midline on<tei:lb/>segments five and six, ventral surface and lateral margins reddish basally; median and posterior femora<tei:lb/>subapically tinged reddish. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline, veins pale yellow. Tegmen with apical<tei:lb/>margin very narrowly reddish brown. Wing unmarked.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>28 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Peru: Callanga (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One of the largest species of the genus, immaculata is distinguished by the lack of pigmentation<tei:lb/>of the tegmen and wing, and by the reddish pigmentation of the head and body.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia hyalina sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 226, 337, 445)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-55 mm long, 0-82 wide; pronotum 1-66 mm wide; tegmen 8-68-8-48 mm long; wing 5-40 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 6 times width at apex, twice width at base; ocelli very small, distinct; clypeus slightly<tei:lb/>longer than frons; rostrum terminating at level of hind coxae. Pronotal width 13 times mid-dorsal length,<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces without carinae; tegula basally carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertex deep red; genae level with midline of eyes dark brown; fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each<tei:lb/>with a broad, horizontal, orange band extending from adjacent to eye to lateral margin; tegula with ventral<tei:lb/>margin dull brown. Tegmen and wing hyaline, veins yellowish. Tegmen with cross-veins and forks of veins<tei:lb/>pale brown; apical fork of medial vein narrowly dark brown; claval margin with a small brown spot at level<tei:lb/>of point of fusion of anal veins, a small brown apot adjacent to claval suture at level of first fork of medial<tei:lb/>vein. Wing with a small pale brown spot adjacent to claval suture at midlength; radial-medial cross-vein<tei:lb/>brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus very slender; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large flap-like processes.<tei:lb/>Paramere very robust; apex obtusely rounded; dorsal process situated at one-third length, small, apex<tei:lb/>strongly produced posteriorly; dorsal surface subbasally produced, bearing numerous, long, robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype d", Jamaica: Moneague, ii.1904 (Walsingham) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 C?, same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the pigmentation of the head and pronotum, the relative<tei:lb/>lack of pigmentation of the tegmen and wing, and by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia unimaculata sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, slightly expanded apically; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large,<tei:lb/>broadly rounded, flap-like processes, each bearing a long tapering spine near base on anterior surface.<tei:lb/>Paramere very slender basally, broadening towards apex; dorsal process situated slightly distad of<tei:lb/>mid-length, very large, not greatly produced; dorsal surface at one-quarter length with a short rounded<tei:lb/>secondary process bearing numerous robust spines.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDHNI (HOMOPTERA) 29</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 5 times width at apex, 2-5 times width at base; ocelli obsolete; clypeus c. as long as<tei:lb/>frons; rostrum terminating at level of hind coxae. Pronotal width 15 times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>carinae distinct; tegulae with carinae obsolete or absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a small dark brown spot adjacent to dorsal margin of eye, occasionally extending onto<tei:lb/>frons, with a similar marking level with mid-line of eye; antenna deep red; lateral surfaces of paraclypeus<tei:lb/>deep red; fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a deep red horizontal band extending from<tei:lb/>adjacent to eye to lateral margin; apices of anterior and medial coxae broadly deep red. Tegmen and wing<tei:lb/>whitish hyaline, veins and cross-veins yellowish. Tegmen with a small dark brown spot on costal cell<tei:lb/>adjacent to first fork of radial vein; clavus with a larger dark brown spot at apex, and a a smaller spot at level<tei:lb/>of point of fusion of anal veins. Wing with a dark brown spot on first branch of cubital vein at midlength;<tei:lb/>posterior margin with a single, semi-circular, dark brown spot between each branch of anal, claval and<tei:lb/>medial veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, cylindrical, asymmetrical; dorsal surface apically with a large, twisted,<tei:lb/>flap-like process terminating anteriorly in a blunt point; left dorso-lateral surface subapically with a large<tei:lb/>triangular process; right lateral surface subapically with a large flap- like process terminating posteriorly in<tei:lb/>an acute spine-like lobe. Paramere very large; apex acute, strongly produced dorsally; dorsal process well<tei:lb/>developed, situated at midlength, apex postero-dorsally directed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Ecuador: Cachabe, i.1897 (Rosenberg) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 cf , same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tegminal and wing pigmentation of this species closely resembles that of acidaloides, but the<tei:lb/>prominent markings of the head and thorax, and the structure of the male genitalia, render it<tei:lb/>readily distinguishable.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, cylindrical ; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of triangular processes, each<tei:lb/>produced posteriorly into a slender, rounded, flap extending beyond apex of shaft; ventral surface apically<tei:lb/>produced into two pairs of large, acute, triangular processes.          <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 33</tei:p>
         <tei:p>as frons; rostrum extending well beyond hind coxae. Pronotal width 20 times mid-dorsal length;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae and fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum adjacent to eyes weakly pale orange; disc of mesonotum<tei:lb/>brownish. Tegmen and wing smoky brown. Tegmen with veins brownish; with a narrow, whitish,<tei:lb/>transverse band at one-fifth length, another at two-fifths; a third at three-fifths; an irregular, broken, band<tei:lb/>at approximately mid-length; posterior margin whitish from apex of first branch of cubital vein to fifth<tei:lb/>branch of medial vein; apical fork of radial vein irregularly pale. Wing pale, whitish hyaline, veins pale;<tei:lb/>with an irregular brownish, transverse band extending from costal margin to base of cubital vein; an<tei:lb/>irregular brownish band extending obliquely from medial-cubital cross-vein to posterior margin; a very<tei:lb/>faint band extending from radial-medial cross-vein almost to posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus broadly laterally expanded subapically ; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large,<tei:lb/>adpressed, overlapping, flap-like processes, each terminating anteriorly in a tapering spine -near midline.<tei:lb/>Paramere massive, apex broadly rounded; dorsal process greatly reduced, situated at one-third length;<tei:lb/>dorsal surface at two-thirds length with a large, conical, secondary process.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Holotype cT, Brazil: Para, Jabaty, v.1924 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 $ , same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is distinguished by the pigmentation of the tegmen and wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia williamsisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 238, 349, 458)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length of frons 5-5 times width at apex, 3 times width at base; ocelli very large and prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>slightly longer than frons; rostrum terminating slightly basad of subgenital plate.          <tei:p>Dorsal surface of mesonotum and abdomen brownish. Tegmen and wing dark, smoky brown, veins<tei:lb/>brownish yellow. Wing with an irregular pale band running transversely from costal margin at level of<tei:lb/>radial-medial cross-vein, becoming broader and less distinct towards posterior margin at level of first two<tei:lb/>branches of cubital vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, cylindrical, slightly asymmetrical; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of<tei:lb/>long, flap-like processes bearing clusters of very small, tooth-like spines apically; dorso-lateral surfaces<tei:lb/>subapically each with a small, spine-like process. Paramere slender; dorsal process large, situated at<tei:lb/>two-thirds length, strongly produced dorsally and posteriorly; dorsal surface subbasally with a cluster of<tei:lb/>short, robust spines; ventral surface subbasally with several long, robust spines.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum at level of eyes each with a prominent, dark brown, roughly circular<tei:lb/>spot, not reaching either internal or lateral margins; tegula tinged brownish on ventral margins; fore tibia<tei:lb/>and tarsus brownish.          <tei:p>38 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is distinguished by the prominent dark spots on the fronto-lateral surfaces of the<tei:lb/>pronotum and the lack of distinct markings on the tegmen and wing; from liquida it is separated<tei:lb/>by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia fuscofrontalissp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 245, 356, 466)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-67 mm long, 0-88 mm wide; pronotum 2-37 mm wide; tegmen 8-90 mm long; wing 5-10 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 4 times width at apex, 2-25 times width at base; ocelli large, not prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>slightly longer than frons; rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Pronotal width 28<tei:lb/>times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral carinae absent; tegula with carinae very prominent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head with base of vertex, and genae from base to level of ventral margins of eyes, bright scarlet;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a narrow, bright scarlet, horizontal band extending from<tei:lb/>adjacent to base of head to lateral margin. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline; veins, excepting subcostal<tei:lb/>and radial veins of tegmen, pale; cross-veins dark brown; posterior and apical margins broadly smoky<tei:lb/>brown between veins. Tegmen with subcostal and radial veins brown over greater part of length basally;<tei:lb/>clavus with a small, dark brown spot between anal veins, another slightly distad of point of fusion of anal<tei:lb/>veins, another subapically; cubital area with four, irregular brownish spots; costal cell dark brown between<tei:lb/>cross-veins, costal margin narrowly scarlet; medial vein with bases of first and second branches, and apical<tei:lb/>fork, dark brown, fifth and sixth branches each with two, evenly spaced, dark brown spots. Wing with first<tei:lb/>fork of cubital vein dark brown; with an irregular, dark brown spot over midlength of first cubital branch;<tei:lb/>second and third cubital branches, and both medial branches, dark brown from base to immediately prior<tei:lb/>to posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender; lateral surfaces subapically each with a large flap-like process, produced<tei:lb/>antero-dorsally into a long curving spine, and with a small spine ventrally. Paramere robust; apex broadly<tei:lb/>rounded, with a long, curving, flap-like process dorsally; dorsal process small, situated at midlength,<tei:lb/>posteriorly produced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Panama: Las Cumbres, 6.vi.l976 (Woldo) (FAMU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the pigmentation of the head, pronotum, tegmen and<tei:lb/>wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia albipennis Westwood<tei:lb/>(Figs 228, 339, 448)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia albipennis Westwood, 1840: 83. LECTOTYPE cf , BRAZIL (UM), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Mysidia parviceps Fowler, 1900: 73. LECTOTYPE $, GUATEMALA (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-63 mm long, 0-80 mm wide; pronotum 1-82 mm wide; tegmen 8-40-9-00 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>5-60 mm long. Female: tegmen 8-84-9-20 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 6 times width at apex, c. twice width at base; ocelli distinct; clypeus c. as long as frons;<tei:lb/>rostrum terminating at level of hind coxae. Pronotal width c. 14 times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces and tegula not distinctly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertex often scarlet from base to level of dorsal margins of eyes; genae each with a narrow, horizontal,<tei:lb/>dark brown/black band extending from adjacent to dorsal margin of eye to anterior margin; fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces of pronotum each with a broad reddish band extending horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral<tei:lb/>margin, this band often incorporating a large black spot in its ventral margin; abdomen with a small,<tei:lb/>circular, black spot on either side of midline on dorsal surface of fifth segment. Tegmen and wing whitish<tei:lb/>hyaline, veins very pale brownish. Tegmen with cross-veins and first and second forks of medial vein dark<tei:lb/>brown; cells between branches of cubital and medial veins each with a smoky brown semicircular spot on<tei:lb/>posterior and apical margins; apical fork of medial vein covered by a prominent, circular, dark brown spot;<tei:lb/>clavus with an irregular dark brown spot between anal veins subbasally, another between fused anal veins<tei:lb/>and claval suture at two-thirds length, another between fused anal veins and posterior margin, and a fourth<tei:lb/>at apex of claval suture. Wing with apical and posterior margins narrowly smoky brown between veins;<tei:lb/>radial-medial cross-vein dark brown, an irregular, dark brown spot between medial and cubital veins at<tei:lb/>two-fifths length, and another between first branch of cubital vein and first anal vein.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 39</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, laterally expanded over apical half; dorsal surface with a pair of large flap-like<tei:lb/>processes arising subapically and extending anteriorly to midlength. Paramere with apex very obtusely<tei:lb/>rounded; dorsal process situated at two-fifths length, small, with apex slender and strongly produced<tei:lb/>posteriorly; dorsal surface subbasally with a group of short robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype C? (albipennis), Brazil: Vera Cruz (UM). Lectotype 9 (parviceps), Guatemala: Zapota<tei:lb/>(Champion) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Honduras: 6 cf , 8 $ , Lancertillo (FAMU; BMNH). Belize: 1 $ (FAMU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Westwood did not indicate the number of specimens in the type-series of albipennis; the single<tei:lb/>male available for study is here designated as lectotype. The three female specimens of parviceps<tei:lb/>described by Fowler are not conspecific. The specimen here designated as lectotype has the<tei:lb/>tegmina damaged; it bears Fowler's handwritten 'type' label.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the distinctive pigmentation of the head and pronotum,<tei:lb/>the mottled appearance of the tegmen and wing, and by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mysidia lactittora Westwood<tei:lb/>Mysidia lactiflora Westwood, 1840: 83. LECTOTYPE $ , BRAZIL (UM), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female: head 0-75 mm long, 0-98 mm wide; pronotum 2-63 wide; tegmen 12-07 mm long; wing 7-00 mm<tei:lb/>long. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 10 times width at apex, 2-5 times width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus one quarter<tei:lb/>longer than frons; rostrum only just reaching hind coxae.          <tei:p>Base of vertex reddish; genae from level of dorsal margins of eyes to level of midline of eyes dull crimson;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a prominent, broad, brownish band extending horizontally<tei:lb/>from adjacent to eye to lateral margin, each band deep red along dorsal margin; tegulae ventral to carinae<tei:lb/>deep brownish. Tegmen with<tei:lb/>first, second and apical forks of medial vein pale brownish; costal cell yellowish brown, bearing a small,<tei:lb/>prominent, roughly circular, dark brown spot at level of first fork of cubital vein, another similar spot<tei:lb/>adjacent to point of separation of fused subcostal and radial veins, a third, smaller spot at c. one-third<tei:lb/>length; with a small, roughly circular, prominent, dark brown spot over cross-vein linking second and third<tei:lb/>branches of medial vein; a small dark brown spot on anal margin somewhat distad of point of fusion of anal<tei:lb/>veins. Wing with cross- veins slightly darker brown than those of tegmen; a small, irregular, indistinct,<tei:lb/>brownish spot over first branch of cubital vein somewhat basad of midlength.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Lectotype $ , Brazil: no further data (UM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lectotype has the abdomen partially eaten away, and the left tegmen and wing glued in<tei:lb/>place; Westwood's 'type' label gives the name as 'lactiflorea'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species, in the absence of reference to the male genitalia, is most readily distinguished by<tei:lb/>its large size, the markings on the fronto-lateral surfaces of the pronotum, and the paucity of<tei:lb/>markings on the tegmina and wings, in particular the absence of a dark spot over the apical fork<tei:lb/>of the medial vein of the tegmen.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The holotype, the other two specimens from the type-locality, and the single specimen from San<tei:lb/>Isidro, all collected by Champion, are part of the Biologia Centrali Americana material, and<tei:lb/>were previously determined as 'costata Fowler'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Externally this species closely resembles costata but is distinguished by the fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces of the pronotum which have a horizontal reddish band; in costata the fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces bear a circular dark brown spot. The structure of the male genitalia is also distinct.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Mysidia diana sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 227, 338, 447)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-63 mm long, 0-80 mm wide; pronotum 1-82 mm wide; tegmen 9-35 mm long; wing 5-53 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female: tegmen 11-22 mm long.</tei:p>

Pronotal width 18 times<tei:lb/>mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces and tegula not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body unmarked. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline. Tegmen with costal margin smoky brown;<tei:lb/>an irregular brownish band extending over first fork of cubital vein almost to vanal fold; indistinct pale<tei:lb/>brown mottling immediately distad of midlength; a small, prominent, dark brown spot over bases of<tei:lb/>fourth, fifth and sixth branches of medial vein; a smaller dark spot on margin over apex of fifth branch of<tei:lb/>medial vein; cross-veins narrowly dark brown. Wing with anal area irregularly mottled smoky brown<tei:lb/>extending over first and second forks of cubital vein; a very large smoky brown area covering radial-medial<tei:lb/>cross-vein and branches of medial vein extending to apical margin between branches of medial and cubital<tei:lb/>veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus robust; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of very large, apically truncate, flap-like<tei:lb/>processes. Paramere broad, apex rounded; dorsal process situated immediately basad of midlength,<tei:lb/>strongly produced posteriorly; internal lateral surface with a low curving ridge bearing robust spines at<tei:lb/>one-quarter length.</tei:p>
