         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Ecuador: Tena, 4.iii.l923 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 10 cf , 21 $, same locality as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Though externally similar to obnubilia, this species is readily distinguished by the structure of<tei:lb/>the aedeagus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DYSIMIA Muir<tei:lb/>Dysimia Muir, 1924: 462. Type-species: Dysimia maculata Muir, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in dorsal aspect one-quarter to two-thirds wider than long. Lateral margins of vertex strongly<tei:lb/>converging from base to level of anterior margins of eyes, then subparallel to apex, carinae very prominent,<tei:lb/>extending beyond anterior margins of eyes for one-quarter to one-third length; basal margin very deeply<tei:lb/>incised; junction with frons broadly rounded. Frons 6-9 times as long as wide at apex, 1-5-2-0 times width<tei:lb/>at base; lateral margins strongly and regularly diverging from apex to base. Genae extending anterior to<tei:lb/>eyes for one-third to two-thirds horizontal diameter of eye. Antenna with second segment club-shaped,<tei:lb/>twice as long as broad; apex transverse; flagellum arising medially. Ocelli small, usually distinct;<tei:lb/>occasionally obscure or obsolete. Clypeus short, broad; length from three-quarters of to equal that of<tei:lb/>frons, from c. equal to up to one-half greater than width at base; medial carina obsolete or absent; lateral<tei:lb/>carinae usually obsolete or absent, occasionally weak and extending over basal c. one-third length.<tei:lb/>Rostrum usually terminating at level of posterior surfaces of hind coxae, occasionally slightly shorter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width 8-12 times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces each with a single, distinct,<tei:lb/>occasionally prominent carina extending horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral margin. Tegula rarely<tei:lb/>carinate. Disc of mesonotum c. as long as wide; medial carina percurrent, often weak or obsolete, rarely<tei:lb/>prominent; lateral carinae commonly obsolete or absent, rarely distinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen commonly 3-20-4-40 mm long, rarely more than 6-00 mm long. Medial vein separating from<tei:lb/>fused subcostal and radial veins at c. one-quarter length; subcostal and radial veins separating at somewhat<tei:lb/>basad of midlength. Radial vein with two branches extending to apical margin. Medial vein with seven<tei:lb/>branches extending to apical and posterior margins; with cross- veins between first and second and second<tei:lb/>and third branches. Cubital vein with three branches extending to posterior margin; anterior branch linked<tei:lb/>by a cross-vein to first medial vein at c. midlength (Fig. 9.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of wing greater than one-half that of legmen. Subcostal and radial veins fused over rather more<tei:lb/>than basal one-half length. Radial vein unbranched. Medial vein distinct from base, unbranched, linked to<tei:lb/>radial vein by a cross-vein at c. two-thirds length. Cubital vein with three branches extending to posterior<tei:lb/>margin, linked to medial vein by a cross-vein at slightly distad of midlength.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body pale, yellowish or brownish. Genae frequently each with a brown band extending<tei:lb/>horizontally from level of dorsal margin of eye to anterior margin, a similar band at level of ventral margin<tei:lb/>of eye, rarely unmarked; area around ocelli occasionally tinged brownish. Frons and clypeus rarely with<tei:lb/>dark markings. Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum usually each with a broad brown band extending<tei:lb/>horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral margin. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline; veins pale yellow;<tei:lb/>cross-veins and forks of veins brownish, often broadly edged smoky brown; apical and posterior marginal<tei:lb/>veins often crimson, or flecked with red. Tegmen with a large, often prominent, black or brownish, roughly<tei:lb/>circular spot at one-fifth to one-third length over first branch of cubital vein; often with smaller but equally<tei:lb/>distinct spots between cubital vein and clavus, adjacent to point of separation of subcostal and radial veins<tei:lb/>and around apical fork of medial vein. Wing often with a large, prominent, circular, dark brown spot<tei:lb/>between cubital vein and clavus at c. one-third length; where marking is absent, often with a pale brown<tei:lb/>transverse band at one-third length.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>88 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, slender, cylindrical, usually symmetrical; dorsal<tei:lb/>surface subapically with a pair of large, anteriorly directed, flap-like processes, often bearing from one to<tei:lb/>three pairs of large, curving, anteriorly or antero-laterally directed spines; ventral surface unarmed.<tei:lb/>Paramere commonly slender, rarely very robust; apex frequently acutely rounded and directed towards<tei:lb/>midline; basal apodeme not more than one-third total length; dorsal process situated at or distad to<tei:lb/>midlength, usually well developed with apex strongly produced posteriorly; interlocking surfaces usually<tei:lb/>well developed, situated basally or at midlength, rarely reduced or absent; dorsal surface basad of main<tei:lb/>process usually with a large, internally directed, secondary process; ventral surface unarmed. Anal tube<tei:lb/>with posterior margin rounded, more or less strongly produced, often deeply notched at midline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female with posterior margin of subgenital plate more or less strongly produced medially, broadly and<tei:lb/>regularly convex, rarely truncate apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus is distinguished by the seven branches of the medial vein of the tegmen, the three<tei:lb/>branches of the cubital vein of the wing and the apical position of the antennal flagellum. This<tei:lb/>last character and the proportions of the frons and clypeus show a closer affinity to Pseudomy-<tei:lb/>sidia than to Mysidia, though it is apparently considerably more specialised than the former.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia show three possible diverging lines of development within the genus, which<tei:lb/>allow the postulation of the following species groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The maculata-gToup. Species where the shaft of the aedeagus is lacking large spines, with a<tei:lb/>corresponding increase in the size and armature of the paramere. The group includes distincta,<tei:lb/>fennahi, pseudomaculata and telfordi, and is probably the most highly specialized of the three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The astarte-group. Species where the shaft of the aedeagus bears strong, heavily chitinized,<tei:lb/>spine-like processes, and the paramere shows a lesser degree of development. This group<tei:lb/>includes morrisi, muiri, obrieni, maculipennis and jamaicensis .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The numa-group. This monotypic group shows a separate line of development from the<tei:lb/>above. The aedeagus is heavily armed with three pairs of long, acute, spine-like processes, and<tei:lb/>the dorsal process of the paramere is greatly reduced and can have little grasping function.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Due to the absence of males, fuscoclypea ta andputilla are omitted from the above groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus is distributed from U.S.A. (Florida) through Central America to Ecuador and<tei:lb/>Venezuela.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Dysimia (based on external characters)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. putilla is omitted from this key due to the fragmentary condition of the unique holotype. In some<tei:lb/>instances the differences between species are slight and, where possible, reference should be made to the<tei:lb/>structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Tegmen exceeding 6 mm. Jamaica jamaicensis (Distant) (p. 91)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen less than 5 mm 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2(1) Wing with a prominent, dark brown, spot adjacent to cubital vein 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing lacking a distinct spot adjacent to cubital vein 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3(2) Genae with dark brown markings adjacent to eye 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae unmarked, pale brownish throughout. Florida pseudomaculata sp. n. (p. 91)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4(3) Tegmen with cross-veins and apical veins dark brown. Costa Rica obrieni sp. n. (p. 92)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen with cross-veins and apical veins pale 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5(4) Male tegmen in excess of 4-00 mm; female with tegmen in excess of 4-50 mm. Tegmen with</tei:p>
         <tei:p>posterior margin narrowly scarlet. Ecuador morrisi sp. n. (p. 93)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neither sex with tegmen exceeding 4-00 mm. Tegmen with posterior margin pale. Jamaica</tei:p>
         <tei:p>muiri sp. n. (p. 92)<tei:lb/>6(2) Clypeus narrowly pale basally, thence dark brown to junction with paraclypeus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venezuela fuscoclypeata Fennah (p. 90)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus pale throughout 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7(6) Genae each with one or two dark brown bands extending horizontally from adjacent to eye</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to anterior margin. Pronotum dorsad of eyes unmarked 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae unmarked. Pronotum dorsad of base of head with two very pale fuscous, parallel,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>transverse bands. Cayman Islands numa Fennah (p. 90)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8(7) Abdomen with a large, dark brown, spot on either side of midline on dorsal surface. Puerto</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rico distincta sp. n. (p. 93), fennahisp. n. (p. 94), telfordisp. n. (p. 94)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with dorsal surface unmarked . . 9</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 89</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9(8) Disc of mesonotum ventrolaterally marked brownish. Venezuela astartesp. n. (p. 95)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Disc of mesonotum unicolorous yellowish throughout 10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10(9) Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum ventral to level of dorsal margins of eye dark brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ecuador macuJipennis sp. n. (p. 95)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum pale brown throughout. Puerto Rico maculate Muir (p. 89)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Dysimia (based on male genitalia)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It has not been possible to examine males oifuscoclypeata andputilla, which are omitted from this key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Paramere with dorsal process bearing a large hook-like spine on dorsal surface (Fig. 1 18)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>distincte sp. n. (p. 93)<tei:lb/>Paramere with dorsal process unarmed on dorsal surface 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 (1) Shaft of aedeagus with three pairs of spine-like processes on dorsal surface subapically</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 95). Paramere with dorsal process reduced (Fig. 119) numa Fennah (p. 90)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus with not more than two pairs of spine-like processes. Paramere with<tei:lb/>dorsal process well developed 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 (2) Shaft of aedeagus devoid of large spine-like processes 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus bearing one or two pairs of large, anteriorly directed, spine-like</tei:p>
         <tei:p>processes subapically 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4(3) Shaft of aedeagus with dorsal surface with a pair of anteriorly directed , flap-like , processes<tei:lb/>subapically, each bearing a very small, antero-laterally directed spine (Fig. 96)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maculate Muir (p. 89)<tei:lb/>Shaft of aedeagus with flap-like processes unarmed 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 (4) Paramere slender, apex acute, dorsal process situated at mid-length (Fig. 121) 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramere robust , dorsal process arising well distad of mid-length (Fig. 123) 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 (5) Paramere with apex of dorsal process horizontally directed; inter-locking surfaces poorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed (Fig. 121) pseudomaculate sp. n. (p. 91)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramere with apex of dorsal process inclined ventrally; interlocking surfaces well<tei:lb/>developed (Fig. 122) muiri sp. n. (p. 92)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 (5) Paramere very robust; apex strongly curved towards midline; dorsal process very long and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>slender; interlocking surfaces situated basally (Fig. 123) fennahi sp. n. (p. 94)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramere relatively small; apex rounded, not curved towards midline; dorsal process<tei:lb/>robust; interlocking surfaces situated at mid-length (Fig. 124) telfordi sp. n. (p. 94)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 (3) Shaft of aedeagus with two pairs of spines subapically on dorsal surface (Fig. 101)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>macuJipennis sp. n. (p. 95)<tei:lb/>Shaft of aedeagus with one pair or three spines subapically on dorsal surface 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 (8) Shaft of aedeagus bearing, in addition to a pair of long, slender, acute spines subapically, a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>single, short, apically obtuse spine at midline (Fig. 102) obrieni sp. n. (p. 92)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus with a single pair of long, curving, spines only 10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 (9) Shaft of aedeagus long and slender ; apical spines simple , long and curving 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus short and broad; apical spines overlaying large, flap-like, anteriorly<tei:lb/>directed processes, each of which bears a short, antero-laterally directed, apically</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bifurcated, subsidiary process baso-laterally (Fig. 103) jamaicensis Distant (p. 91)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11(10) Paramere with a large, rounded, secondary process on dorsal surface subbasally (Fig. 128)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>morrisi sp. n. (p. 93)<tei:lb/>Paramere without a secondary process (Fig. 129) asterte sp. n. (p. 95)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia maculata Muir</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 9, 13,29,96, 108, 120)<tei:lb/>Dysimia maculata Muir, 1924: 463. Holotype C?, PUERTO Rico (BPBM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-30 mm long, 0-40 mm wide; pronotum 0-80 mm wide; tegmen 3-60-3-75 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>2-30 mm long. Female: tegmen 3-80-4-40 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 8 times width at apex, 1-66 times width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus c.<tei:lb/>three-quarters length of frons. Pronotal width c. 12 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a broad, brown band at level of eye, darker at dorsal and ventral margins, extending<tei:lb/>horizontally to anterior margin; area around ocelli frequently brownish; frons with base occasionally dark<tei:lb/>brown. Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a brownish band extending horizontally from</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>90 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>adjacent to eye to external margin. Tegmen and wing with bases of branches of veins and cross- veins<tei:lb/>brownish, cross-veins edged pale smoky brown; posterior and apical margins frequently very narrowly<tei:lb/>edged scarlet. Tegmen with a large, circular, dark brown spot over first branch of cubital vein at one-third<tei:lb/>length; a smaller spot between cubital vein and clavus at one-sixth length; another adjacent to and<tei:lb/>immediately basad of subcostal and fused radial-medial fork; a third small spot, more irregular and less<tei:lb/>distinct, around fused subcostal-radial-medial vein at one-third length. Wing with a prominent, circular,<tei:lb/>dark brown spot between cubital vein and clavus at one-quarter length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender , with two pairs of flap- like processes , the external pair each with a small , blunt ,<tei:lb/>spine on ventral surface. Paramere with dorsal process situated slightly distad of midlength, slender,<tei:lb/>strongly produced postero-dorsally; dorsal surface at one-quarter length with a slender, regularly tapering,<tei:lb/>secondary process bearing long, robust, spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Puerto Rico: Rio Piedras, viii.1923 (Wolcott) (BPBM).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Puerto Rico: 26 cf , 13 $, same data as holotype (BMNH); 1 cf (USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species has also been recorded from Haiti (Dozier, 1922). The specimens recorded by Ball<tei:lb/>(1928) from Florida are the newly described species pseudomaculata (p. 00). The two species are<tei:lb/>readily distinguished by the absence of the dark spot on the wing of pseudomaculata, and by the<tei:lb/>male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimht fuscoclypeata Fennah</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia fuscodypeata Fennah, 1952: 124. Holotype $, VENEZUELA: Aragua, Rancho Grande, 1100 m,<tei:lb/>l.x.1950 (Yepez) (lost). NEOTYPE $, VENEZUELA, here designated (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female: head 0-30 mm long, 0-42 mm wide; pronotum 0-86 mm wide; legmen 4-40 mm long; wing 2-60 mm<tei:lb/>long. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 7 times width at apex, 1-5 times width at base; ocelli distinct; clypeus c. as long as frons,<tei:lb/>1-5 times width at base. Pronotal width c. 8 times mid-dorsal length; tegula weakly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frons with apical half somewhat darker than basal half, with a dark brown transverse band at level of<tei:lb/>dorsal margin of eye and another at midline; genae irregularly reddish brown, with a dull brown band<tei:lb/>running from level of midline of eye to anterior margin; clypeus with basal quarter whitish, thence brown to<tei:lb/>junction with pale yellowish paraclypeus. Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a broad brown<tei:lb/>band extending horizontally from adjacent to eye, terminating short of external margin; metanotum with<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces at level of clypeus pale brown. Tegmen and wing with cross-veins narrowly edged<tei:lb/>smoky brown. Tegmen with a very large, prominent, dark brown spot on first branch of cubital vein at<tei:lb/>one-third length; a much smaller spot adjacent and anterior to medial vein at equi-distance from base; two<tei:lb/>small spots at one-seventh length, one between fused subcostal, radial and medial veins and costal margin,<tei:lb/>and the other immediately posterior to cubital vein. Wing with a single, irregular, dark brown spot at<tei:lb/>two-fifths length, adjacent to and posterior to cubital vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Neotype $ , Venezuela: Aragua, Camino, Choroni, 950 m, montane forest, 24.iii.1949 (Box) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This is the only specimen available for study. A pin with a label bearing the data of the holotype<tei:lb/>is in the BMNH, but the specimen is missing. With Dr Fennah's agreement I therefore designate<tei:lb/>the single paratype as a neotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the name suggests, fuscodypeata is readily distinguished by the dark pigmentation of the<tei:lb/>clypeus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia numa Fennah</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 95, 107, 119)<tei:lb/>Dysimia numa Fennah, 1971: 324. Holotype cf , CAYMAN ISLANDS (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-28 mm long, 0-40 mm wide; pronotum 0-72 mm wide; tegmen 3-60-4-20 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>2-00 mm long. Female: tegmen 4-00-4-60 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 6 times width at apex, 1-5 times width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus as long as<tei:lb/>frons. Pronotal width 10 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head unmarked; pronotum with a pale fuscous transverse band parallel to posterior margin on dorsal</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 91</tei:p>
         <tei:p>surface; fronto-lateral surfaces each with a very faint fuscous band extending horizontally from adjacent to<tei:lb/>dorsal margin of eye to lateral margin. Tegmen and wing with cross-veins and forks of veins faintly edged<tei:lb/>brownish. Tegmen with a large, prominent, roughly circular, brown spot over first branch of cubital vein at<tei:lb/>three-fifths length; a smaller, paler, irregular marking over apical fork of medial vein; two smaller spots,<tei:lb/>one between cubital vein and clavus, the other between point of separation of medial vein from fused<tei:lb/>subcostal-radial veins and costal margin; an irregular spot over medial and fused subcostal-radial veins at<tei:lb/>three-eighths length. Wing with a small dark brown spot immediately basad of one-third length, adjacent<tei:lb/>to cubital vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus laterally expanded over apical one-third length, with three pairs of large spine-like<tei:lb/>processes. Paramere slender; apex acute; dorsal process situated at two-thirds length, greatly reduced,<tei:lb/>with a posteriorly directed spine on posterior surface at midlength; dorsal surface at one-third length with<tei:lb/>an apically rounded secondary process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Grand Cayman: N. Coast, N. Side, Hut Rd, 15.vii.1938 (Lewis &amp; Thompson) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Cayman Brae: 38 cf , 33 $ , Statae [?] Bay (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his description Fennah erroneously refers to a single pair of spines on the aedeagus; his<tei:lb/>illustration correctly shows three.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is distinguished by the lack of dark pigmentation on the genae and pronotum, and<tei:lb/>by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimiajamaicensis Distant comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 103, 115, 127)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length of frons 6 times width at apex, twice width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus two-thirds longer<tei:lb/>than frons. Pronotal width 12 times mid-dorsal length; tegula carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae and fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum at level of eyes brown. Tegmen and wing with veins and<tei:lb/>cross-veins narrowly and irregularly edged pale brownish, posterior margins between veins broadly smoky<tei:lb/>brown, posterior marginal veins crimson. Tegmen with a large irregular brown spot over fork of second<tei:lb/>branch of medial vein; a smaller spot over apical fork of medial vein; another larger spot between first<tei:lb/>branch of cubital vein and vanal fold at approximately three-quarters length of clavus. Wing with<tei:lb/>cross-veins brown; an indistinct, broken, pale brownish, transverse band at one-third length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus bearing a pair of large, flap-like processes, each with an adjacent spine-like process<tei:lb/>dorsally and a small, apically bifurcate spine laterally.          <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Lectotype cf , Jamaica: Moneague, 10.ii.1905 (Nicholl) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is included in Dysimia because of the tegminal venation and the proportions of the<tei:lb/>head. Its relatively large size and long wings, with the reduction in the dorsal process of the<tei:lb/>paramere and complex armature of the aedeagus, readily distinguish it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia pseudomaculata sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Head ventral to dorsal margins of eyes brown, genae lacking distinct darker markings. Fronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces of pronotum ventral to horizontal carinae pale dull brownish. Tegmen and wing with veins and<tei:lb/>cross-veins predominantly pale brown; marginal veins very narrowly crimson, broadly and irregularly</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>92 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>edged pale smoky brown. Tegmen with a very large, prominent, circular, dark brown spot over first branch<tei:lb/>of cubital vein immediately basad of level of apex of clavus; a small, dark brown spot between cubital vein<tei:lb/>and claval suture subbasally; a somewhat smaller spot on costal cell immediately basad of point of<tei:lb/>separation of fused radial and medial veins; a small, indistinct spot over medial vein at one-third length; an<tei:lb/>irregular, fainter spot covering apical forks of medial and radial veins; bases of branches of medial vein<tei:lb/>occasionally dark brown.          <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus strongly dorsally and laterally expanded subapically, devoid of spines. Paramere<tei:lb/>slender; apex acute; dorsal process situated at midlength, apex strongly produced posteriorly; dorsal<tei:lb/>surface slightly basad of one-third length with a secondary process bearing a few long, robust, spines.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The genitalic differences are consistent, though not great, but the lack of a prominent dark spot<tei:lb/>on the wing of pseudomaculata renders the species readily distinguishable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia muiri sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 8 times width at apex, twice width at base; ocelli distinct; clypeus c. three-quarters<tei:lb/>length of frons. Pronotal width c. 9 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a dark brown band extending horizontally from level of dorsal margin of eye to anterior<tei:lb/>margin; another similar band at level of ventral margin of eye. Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each<tei:lb/>with a broad brown band extending from adjacent to eye horizontally to exterior margin; tegula with<tei:lb/>ventral margin narrowly brown; abdomen with a large, circular, dark brown spot on either side of midline<tei:lb/>subapically on dorsal surface. Tegmen and wing with cross-veins broadly edged very pale brown. Tegmen<tei:lb/>with anterior and posterior margins very narrowly and intermittently tinged reddish; a large, circular, dark<tei:lb/>brown spot on cubital vein at one-third length; a somewhat smaller spot on medial vein equidistant from<tei:lb/>base; an irregular spot over apical fork of medial vein; two smaller spots, one adjacent to fused subcostal,<tei:lb/>radial and medial veins at one-fifth length, the other posterior to cubital vein equidistant from base. Wing<tei:lb/>with posterior margin narrowly tinged reddish, a small brown spot immediately posterior to cubital vein at<tei:lb/>one-third length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus lacking spine-like processes, laterally somewhat expanded over apical one-half length;<tei:lb/>dorsal surface subapically with a transverse, membranous, flap-like process, partially overlying a pair of<tei:lb/>slender, projections situated one on either side of midline. Paramere complex, robust; dorsal process very<tei:lb/>large, situated immediately distad of mid-length, apex strongly produced posteriorly, bearing a large,<tei:lb/>robust, internally curving, hook-like process dorsally; dorsal surface basad of midlength with a shallowly<tei:lb/>bifurcate secondary process.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>94 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Puerto Rico: 8 miles E. of Mayaguez, 9.ii.l969 (O'Brien) (FAMU).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Puerto Rico: 1 cf , Rio Piedras, 4.xii.l968 (Telford &amp; Medina) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although very similar in external characters to fennahi and telfordi, this species is readily<tei:lb/>distinguished by the unique development of the paramere, which here reaches a degree of<tei:lb/>complexity not seen elsewhere during the present study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia fennahi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-29 mm long, 0-42 mm wide; pronotum 0-80 mm wide; tegmen 3-60 mm long; wing 2-00 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 8 times width at apex, twice width at base; ocelli obscure; clypeus three-quarters<tei:lb/>length of frons. Pronotal width slightly less than 8 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a dark brown band running horizontally from level of dorsal margin of eye to anterior<tei:lb/>margin , another similar parallel band at level of ventral margin of eye . Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum<tei:lb/>each with a broad dark brown band running horizontally from adjacent to eye to exterior margin; tegula<tei:lb/>with ventral margin broadly dark brown; abdomen with a large, rather irregular, dark brown spot on either<tei:lb/>side of midline subbasally on dorsal surface. Tegmen and wing with veins and cross-veins narrowly and<tei:lb/>intermittently edged brownish, anterior and posterior margins very narrowly and irregularly flecked pale<tei:lb/>reddish. Tegmen with a large, roughly circular, dark brown spot on first branch of cubital vein at<tei:lb/>approximately one-third length; a somewhat smaller spot on medial vein equidistant from base; an<tei:lb/>irregularly shaped, brownish marking over apical fork of medial vein; two small, dark brown spots, one<tei:lb/>adjacent to fused subcostal, radial and medial veins, the other on cubital vein subbasally. Wing with a<tei:lb/>small, circular, dark brown spot adjacent to cubital vein at one-third length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus with apical third length weakly expanded dorso-late rally; dorsal surface subapically<tei:lb/>with a large, transverse, flap-like process and a pair of spine-like processes adjacent to midline. Paramere<tei:lb/>massive; apex acutely rounded; dorsal process situated at two-thirds length, apex slender and strongly<tei:lb/>produced postero-dorsally; dorsal surface with a well-developed secondary process slightly basad of<tei:lb/>midlength.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cf , Puerto Rico: 8 miles E. of Mayaguez, 9.H.1969 (O'Brien) (FAMU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Externally, this species closely resembles telfordi, from which it is most readily distinguished by<tei:lb/>the structure of the male genitalia, where the reduction in the armature of the aedeagus is<tei:lb/>accompanied by massive development of the paramere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia telfordi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 100, 112, 124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-26 mm long, 0-42 mm wide; pronotum 0-75 mm wide; tegmen 3-40-3-60 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>2-16 mm long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 7 times width at apex, twice width at base; ocelli indistinct; clypeus three-quarters length<tei:lb/>of frons. Pronotal width c. 8 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a dark brown band extending horizontally from adjacent to dorsal margin of eye to<tei:lb/>anterior margin, a similar band at level of ventral margin of eye, these bands continued over frons;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a broad pale brown band extending horizontally from<tei:lb/>adjacent to eye to lateral margin; tegula with ventral margin dark brown; abdomen with a large, roughly<tei:lb/>circular, dark brown spot on either side of midline subapically on dorsal surface. Tegmen and wing with<tei:lb/>cross-veins narrowly edged pale smoky brown. Tegmen with anterior and posterior marginal veins<tei:lb/>crimson; a large, circular, dark brown spot on first branch of cubital vein at one-third length; a rather<tei:lb/>similar spot on medial vein equidistant from base; another over apical fork of medial vein; two smaller<tei:lb/>spots, one immediately anterior to point of separation of fused subcostal, radial and medial veins, the other<tei:lb/>posterior to cubital vein subbasally. Wing with posterior marginal vein crimson; a small, distinct, circular,<tei:lb/>brown spot immediately posterior to cubital vein at one-third length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus weakly expanded over apical two-fifths length; dorsal surface subapically with a<tei:lb/>transverse, flap-like, membranous projection, partially obscuring a pair of short, blunt, spine-like<tei:lb/>processes medially. Paramere robust; dorsal process situated at three-quarters length, strongly produced<tei:lb/>posteriorly; dorsal surface at midlength with an apically bifurcate secondary process.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 95</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Puerto Rico: Rio Piedras, 4.xii.l968 (Telford &amp; Medina) (FAMU).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 5 cf , 1 $ , same data as holotype (FAMU; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Closely resembling fennahi in external characters, this species may be distinguished by its<tei:lb/>smaller size; though the structure of the aedeagus differs only slightly, that of the paramere is<tei:lb/>quite distinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia astarte sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 105, 117, 129)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-29 mm long, 0-40 mm wide; pronotum 0-74 mm wide; tegmen 3-80-3-95 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>2-30 mm long. Female: tegmen 4-10-4-40 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 6 times width at base; c. 2-5 times width at base; ocelli large, not prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>two-thirds length of frons. Pronotal width 9 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each bearing an irregular dark brown band adjacent to dorsal margin of eye, this band often<tei:lb/>extending onto frons, a similar, broader band level with midline of eye; ocelli pale; apices of second<tei:lb/>antennal segments brownish. Pronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum adjacent to eyes narrowly and irregular-<tei:lb/>ly dark brown; mesonotum with a large, irregular, pale brown spot on each side ventro-laterally. Tegmen<tei:lb/>and wing with cross-veins brownish, narrowly edged pale brown, marginal veins yellowish. Tegmen very<tei:lb/>faintly and irregularly mottled greyish brown distad of medial-cubital cross-vein; with a small, circular,<tei:lb/>dark brown spot on subcostal cell, between cubital vein and claval suture at one-sixth length, another over<tei:lb/>medial vein at slightly basad of one-third length, a fourth, rather larger and more irregular spot over first<tei:lb/>branch of cubital vein at one-third length. Wing with a small, irregular, brown spot between cubital vein<tei:lb/>and claval suture at slightly basad of two-fifths length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus not apically expanded ; with a pair of large , flap-like processes extending ventrally over<tei:lb/>lateral surfaces; a pair of acute, spine-like processes adjacent to midline. Paramere slender; apex acute;<tei:lb/>dorsal process large, situated at approximately midlength.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Venezuela: San Esteban, Carabobo, 2.ii.l920 (Williamson &amp; Ditzler} (USNM).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 3 cf , 2 $, same data as holotype (USNM; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the pigmentation of the fronto-lateral surfaces of the<tei:lb/>pronotum, and by the structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia maculipennissp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length of frons 8 times width at apex , twice width at base ; ocelli small , distinct ; clypeus two-thirds length<tei:lb/>of frons. Pronotal width 10 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae at level of eyes each with a broad, horizontal brown band, darkest at upper and lower margins,<tei:lb/>extending from adjacent to eye to anterior margin and continuing across frons; head dorsad of upper<tei:lb/>margins of eyes very pale, whitish. Wing with a pale brown spot immediately distad of first fork<tei:lb/>of cubital vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender in dorsal aspect; a pair of large, flap-like processes, each bearing a pair of long,<tei:lb/>robust spines dorso-laterally. Paramere slender; apex narrowly rounded; dorsal process situated at<tei:lb/>midlength, apex strongly produced posteriorly, dorsal surface at one-quarter length with an irregularly<tei:lb/>rounded secondary process bearing scattered, robust spines.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>96 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Ecuador, Tena, 4.iii.l923 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 1 C?, 2 $ , same data as holotype (BMNH; BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The four specimens in the series bear 'paratype' labels similar to those used by Muir, and the<tei:lb/>series is labelled as 'maculipennis Muir'; however, a search of the literature reveals no record of<tei:lb/>this name ever having been published by Muir. The name maculipennis is used here to avoid any<tei:lb/>possible confusion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is distinguished by the pigmentation of the head and tegmen, and by the structure<tei:lb/>of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomen dubium</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimia putilla Fennah<tei:lb/>Dysimia putilla Fennah, 1952: 124. Holotype &lt;j&gt;, ST LUCIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female: tegmen 4-40 mm long; wing (damaged) 2+ mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head lost. Pronotum with fronto-lateral surfaces distinctly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen and wing with veins pale brown. Tegmen with a small, circular, brownish spot on medial vein at<tei:lb/>one- third length; another, slightly larger spot on first fork of cubital vein equidistant from base; another<tei:lb/>adjacent to apical fork of medial vein; smaller and less distinct pale brownish markings at level of<tei:lb/>separation of medial from fused radial and subcostal veins, and at midlength of cubital vein. Wing with a<tei:lb/>small, roughly circular, pale brown spot adjacent to and basad of first fork of cubital vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, St. Lucia: Quilesse, mountain forest, 1000 ft, 22.ii.1941 (Fennah) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species was described from a unique female of which only a few fragments stored in alcohol<tei:lb/>now remain, thus making an adequate re-description impossible. Fennah stressed the similarity<tei:lb/>of the species to maculata, but also the differences in its markings; in his description he stated:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Basad portion of frons, excluding the secretory pits, a single narrow stripe on side of head before<tei:lb/>eyes, a minute spot on genae above base of antennae, dark fuscous. A broad area on lateral lobes of<tei:lb/>pro no turn, posterior margin of tegulae, and a slight suffusion on mesonotum light sepia-brown to<tei:lb/>fuscous; abdomen with third segment sublaterally, fourth prominently laterally and with four short<tei:lb/>antero-posterior stripes between them, fifth with four paler spots, and sixth with two pale submedian<tei:lb/>spots and two spots laterally fuscous. and [Tegminal] veins interruptedly and diffusely<tei:lb/>overlain with fuscous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subgenital sternite is figured, and described as: . . . produced caudad in a subequilaterally<tei:lb/>triangular lobe with the apex shortly truncate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DYSIMIELLA gen. n.<tei:lb/>Type-species: Dysimiella penny isp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head one-quarter to two-thirds greater than length in dorsal aspect. Vertex c. 1 -25 times as long as<tei:lb/>wide; lateral margins strongly and regularly converging from base to level of anterior margins of eyes,<tei:lb/>thence parallel to junction with frons; extending for c. one-third its length beyond anterior margins of eyes;<tei:lb/>base very deeply incised medially; lateral carinae very prominent. Length of frons 9 times width at apex, c.<tei:lb/>twice width at base; junction with vertex broadly and regularly rounded; lateral margins from apex initially<tei:lb/>gradually and regularly diverging, then abruptly and strongly diverging to base; carinae very prominent.<tei:lb/>Genae extending anterior to eyes for c. one-third to one-half horizontal diameter of eye. Second antennal<tei:lb/>segment club shaped, c. 1-5 times as long as wide; apex truncate; flagellum arising apically. Ocelli<tei:lb/>prominent or obsolete. Clypeus short and broad, shorter than frons, as long as basal width; medial carina<tei:lb/>obsolete; lateral carinae distinct basally. Rostrum not extending beyond hind coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width 11-24 times mid-dorsal length, strongly constricted medially; fronto-lateral surfaces each<tei:lb/>with a single carina curving horizontally from adjacent to midline of eye to lateral margin. Tegula with<tei:lb/>carina weak or absent. Disc of mesonotum slightly wider than long; medial carina weak; lateral carinae<tei:lb/>obsolete or absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen short and broad; length 4-00-5-20 mm, little greater than twice width. Cubital vein with four<tei:lb/>branches extending to posterior margin; first and second, and third and fourth linked by cross- veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 97</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medial vein fused with radial and subcostal veins over basal one-fifth length; forking at two-fifths and<tei:lb/>three-fifths length and apically; with seven branches extending to posterior and apical margins; first fork<tei:lb/>linked to cubital vein by a short cross- vein subbasally; linked to radial vein by a cross- vein slightly distad of<tei:lb/>second fork. Radial vein fused to subcostal vein over basal two-fifths length; two branches extending to<tei:lb/>apical margin; linked to subcostal vein by a cross-vein subapically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing short and broad; length two-thirds that of legmen, twice maximum width; apex broadly truncate.<tei:lb/>Cubital vein with three branches extending to posterior margin. Medial vein unbranched, linked to cubital<tei:lb/>by a cross-vein slightly distad of the second fork of the latter. Radial vein unbranched, linked to medial by a<tei:lb/>single cross-vein slightly basad of three-quarters length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, cylindrical, symmetrical, heavily armed on dorsal<tei:lb/>surface subapically. Paramere with dorsal process well developed. Subgenital plate with posterior margin<tei:lb/>narrowly and prominently produced at midline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimiella is represented in Brazil and Guyana. The venation of the tegmen and the distinctive<tei:lb/>proportions of the head and pronotum indicate a close relationship to Dysimia; the structure of<tei:lb/>the male genitalia, in particular the subgenital plate, is unique.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Dysimiella</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Tegmen and wing with distinct dark transverse bands. Aedeagus with three pairs of spines (Fig.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>154) williamsi sp. n. (p. 97)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Tegmen and wing without distinct transverse markings. Aedeagus with large flap-like processes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and a single pair of long slender spines (Fig. 155) penny! sp. n. (p. 97)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimiella williamsi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 3, 17,32, 154, 156, 158)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-38 mm long, 0-48 mm wide; pronotum 0-90 mm wide; tegmen 4-00-4-20 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>2-65 mm long. Female: tegmen 4-60-4-80 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 9 times width at apex, c. twice width at base; ocelli obsolete; clypeus slightly shorter than<tei:lb/>frons. Pronotal width c. 11 times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral carinae distinct; tegula weakly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genae each with a brown band extending horizontally from adjacent to centre of eye to anterior margin.<tei:lb/>Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum each with a brown band extending horizontally from adjacent to<tei:lb/>midline of eye to lateral margin, and continued over lower surface of tegula. Tegmen and wing whitish<tei:lb/>hyaline, cross- veins edged dark brown. Tegmen with a broad, irregular, pale brownish, transverse band at<tei:lb/>one-fifth length; apical fork of medial vein covered by a large, very prominent, dark brown spot; costal and<tei:lb/>posterior margins very narrowly, regularly intermittently, flecked with crimson. Wing with a distinct, very<tei:lb/>pale brown, transverse band at one-quarter length, posterior margin very narrowly flecked with crimson.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, with three pairs of strong, curving spines subapically. Paramere robust; dorsal<tei:lb/>process situated slightly distad of midlength, apex strongly produced postero-dorsally; dorsal surface<tei:lb/>without a secondary process. Subgenital plate with posterior margin strongly and narrowly produced<tei:lb/>medially into a very long, slender, apically acute spine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Brazil: Para, Jabaty, v.1924 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Brazil: 11 cf , 17 $, same data as holotype; nr Manaus (BMNH; INPA).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the prominent markings on the tegmen, and by the<tei:lb/>structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dysimiella penny i sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 155, 157, 159, 160)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Length of frons 9 times width at apex, 1-66 times width at base; ocelli large, prominent; clypeus<tei:lb/>three-fifths as long as frons. Pronotal width 24 times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral carinae weak; tegula<tei:lb/>not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body pale yellowish brown; lateral carinae of frons, tibiae and tarsi darker brownish. Tegmen<tei:lb/>and wing hyaline, veins pale. Tegmen with veins and cross-veins narrowly edged pale smoky brown, with a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>98 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>darker brownish spot over point of separation of fused radial and subcostal veins, another over apical forks<tei:lb/>of radial and medial veins, apical cells between branches of radial and medial veins each with a slender,<tei:lb/>longitudinal, brownish stripe medially. Wing unmarked. Female with subgenital plate dark brownish,<tei:lb/>ventro-lateral angles of adjacent segment brownish black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus slender, broadening slightly at two-thirds length; a large, rounded, flap-like process<tei:lb/>medially, bearing on each side posteriorly a very long curving spine; lateral surfaces each produced into an<tei:lb/>acute, ventrally directed flap. Paramere slender; apex narrowly rounded; dorsal process situated at<tei:lb/>two-thirds length, dorsally produced but hardly inclined posteriorly; dorsal surface strongly and obtusely<tei:lb/>produced at midlength, acutely produced subapically. Subgenital plate narrowly produced medially into a<tei:lb/>long, slender, apically somewhat expanded and deeply and narrowly notched, spine-liked process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Brazil: Amazonas, P. das Laranjeiras, 28.vii.1981 (Arias) (INPA).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 2 $, same data as holotype (INPA; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by the lack of a distinct transverse band on the tegmen, and<tei:lb/>by the structure of the male genitalia, including the medial process of the subgenital plate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MYSIDALOIDESgen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Mysidaloides trinidadensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head in dorsal aspect greater than 1-5 times length. Vertex hardly extending anterior to eyes;<tei:lb/>lateral margins weakly carinate, very abruptly converging from base to level of midline of eyes, then<tei:lb/>gradually and regularly converging to apex; basal margin transverse; junction with frons broadly and<tei:lb/>regularly rounded. Frons exceeding narrow apically; length greater than 10 times width at apex, less than 3<tei:lb/>times width at base; lateral margins strongly carinate, parallel from apex to level of ventral margins of eyes,<tei:lb/>then strongly diverging to base. Genae extending anterior to eyes for one-eighth horizontal diameter of<tei:lb/>eye. Eyes extremely large, prominent, almost hemispherical. Antenna cylindrical; second segment more<tei:lb/>than 5 times as long as wide; flagellum arising at c. two-thirds length; apex acutely rounded. Ocelli very<tei:lb/>small, not prominent. Rostrum terminating somewhat posterior to hind coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width more than 20 times mid-doral length; very deeply and regularly constricted medially;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces each with a distinct carina curving horizontally from adjacent to midline of eye to<tei:lb/>lateral margin. Tegula not carinate. Disc of mesonotum broader than long; not distinctly carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen 3 times as long as wide. Medial vein separating from fused radial and subcostal veins at<tei:lb/>one-eighth length; radial and subcostal veins separating slightly distad of one-third length. Radial vein with<tei:lb/>two branches extending to apical margin, linked to medial vein by a cross- vein at two-thirds length and at<tei:lb/>level of apical fork. Medial vein forking slightly basad of, and again slightly distad of, midlength; with seven<tei:lb/>branches extending to apical and posterior margins, second and third, and fourth and fifth linked by<tei:lb/>cross-veins. Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin, first linked to apex of clavus<tei:lb/>and to second, second to third, third to fourth, and fourth to first branch of medial vein by cross-veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of wing slightly greater than one-half of that of tegmen. Radial and subcostal veins fused over c.<tei:lb/>basal one-third length. Radial vein unbranched, linked to medial vein by a cross-vein at two-thirds length.<tei:lb/>Medial vein distinct throughout, with two branches extending to apical margin, linked to third branch of<tei:lb/>cubital vein by a cross-vein slightly distad of midlength. Cubital vein with three branches extending to<tei:lb/>posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body uniformly pale, lacking distinct markings. Tegmen and wing hyaline, also lacking distinct<tei:lb/>markings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, cylindrical, symmetrical, slender; dorsal surface<tei:lb/>subapically bearing well-developed flap-like and spine-like processes. Paramere with dorsal process well<tei:lb/>developed, without a distinct secondary process; ventral surface unarmed. Anal tube little produced<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Female with posterior margin of subgenital plate not produced posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The venation of the tegmen and wing of this genus is similar to that of Mysidia, but it differs in<tei:lb/>head characters, in particular the large size of the eyes, the very slender apical portion of the<tei:lb/>frons and the extreme length of the antennae. The genus is monotypic and is known from Brazil,<tei:lb/>Guyana and Trinidad.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>99<tei:lb/>Mysidaloides trinidadensissp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 10, 16,24, 130, 131,132)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-38 mm long, 0-65 mm wide; pronotum 1-32 mm wide; tegmen 6-30 mm long; wing 3-40 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female: tegmen 7-40 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 12 times width at apex, 2-33 times width at base; ocelli indistinct; clypeus as long as frons.<tei:lb/>Pronotal width 22 times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral carinae distinct; tegula without carinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body unmarked. Tegmen and wing hyaline, veins pale yellow. Tegmen unmarked except for a<tei:lb/>very indistinct, pale smoky, transverse band extending from second branch of cubital vein to apex of<tei:lb/>clavus. Wing with posterior margin between branches of cubital vein and apex of radial vein pale smoky<tei:lb/>brown, otherwise unmarked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus somewhat expanded subapically; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of large,<tei:lb/>flap-like processes extending to midlength, each terminating in an antero-dorsally directed projection at<tei:lb/>midline; a pair of diverging spines at midlength. Paramere basally slender, apex broadly rounded; dorsal<tei:lb/>process situated slightly distad of midlength, not greatly produced posteriorly; dorsal surface at approx-<tei:lb/>imately one-third length with a low, rounded projection bearing a cluster of robust, internally directed<tei:lb/>spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cT, Guyana: Tumatumari, 19.vii.1923 (Williams) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Guyana: 1 cf , same data as holotype (BMNH). Trinidad: 1 cf , Aripo Valley (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Brazil: 9 cf , Amazonas, Manaus (INPA; BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOMYSIDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Neomysidia willisisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head considerably greater than length in dorsal aspect. Vertex slightly longer than wide at base;<tei:lb/>extending less than one-quarter its length beyond anterior margins of eyes; lateral carinae low, very<tei:lb/>gradually converging from base to apex; basal margin very weakly concave; junction with frons broadly<tei:lb/>and regularly rounded. Frons parallel-sided from apex to immediately above base, thence lateral margins<tei:lb/>strongly divergent; c. 2-5 times as long as width at apex, little longer than width at base. Genae extending<tei:lb/>beyond anterior margins of eyes for one-third horizontal diameter of eye. Second antennal segment ovate,<tei:lb/>c. twice as long as broad; apex rounded; flagellum arising subapically. Ocelli large and distinct. Clypeus<tei:lb/>broad, rounded, longer than frons; length one and two-thirds width at base; lacking distinct medial and<tei:lb/>lateral carinae. Rostrum terminating at level of mid coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width slightly greater than 7 times length mid-dorsally; not strongly constricted medially;<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces each with a distinct carina curving horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral<tei:lb/>margin. Tegula not carinate. Disc of mesonotum c. 1-5 times as wide as long; broadly triangular; medial<tei:lb/>carina distinct only at midlength; lateral carinae absent or obsolete.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen length c. 6 mm, 2-5 times maximum breadth. Medial vein distinct from fused radial and<tei:lb/>subcostal veins throughout; forking slightly basad and slightly distad of midlength, with seven branches<tei:lb/>extending to posterior and apical margins. Radial and subcostal veins separating at midlength; radial with<tei:lb/>two branches extending to apical margin; linked to subcostal vein by a cross-vein subapically, and to medial<tei:lb/>vein at c. two-fifths length. Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin, the first and<tei:lb/>second, and third and fourth linked by cross-veins (Fig. 6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing almost twice as long as wide, more than half length of tegmen; apex rounded. Subcostal and radial<tei:lb/>veins fused from base to slightly basad of midlength, unbranched; radial vein linked to medial by a<tei:lb/>cross-vein slightly distad of midlength. Medial vein with two branches extending to post-apical margin;<tei:lb/>linked to cubital vein by a cross-vein at c. midlength. Cubital vein two branched.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, symmetrical; dorsal surface heavily armed subapically.<tei:lb/>Paramere with dorsal process reduced; dorsal surface with a secondary process subbasally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus is readily distinguished by the proportions of the head; especially the very short and<tei:lb/>broad frons, the relatively unconstricted dorsal surface of the pronotum, and the short,<tei:lb/>triangular, mesonotal disc.<tei:lb/>Known only from Brazil.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>100 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neomysidia willisisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 6, 18,31,161,165, 169)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-42 mm long, 0-71 mm wide; pronotum 1-58 mm wide; legmen 6-20 mm long; wing 3-50 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 2-5 times width at apex, one-quarter greater than width at base; ocelli large, distinct;<tei:lb/>clypeus one-third longer than frons. Pronotal width 7-5 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertex, genae ventral to eyes, antennae, base of frons, lateral surfaces of clypeus, a small spot on<tei:lb/>fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum above each eye, and dorsal margins of tegula dark brown. Tegmen and<tei:lb/>wing hyaline, veins pale yellowish, cross- veins very narrowly dark brown, posterior and apical margins<tei:lb/>with dark brown spots over apices of veins. Tegmen with radial, medial and cubital areas basally irregularly<tei:lb/>mottled dark smoky brown ; an irregular dark brown spot immediately distad of apex of clavus ; a very dark ,<tei:lb/>almost black spot over apical fork of medial vein. Wing with a short, oblique, irregular, transverse smoky<tei:lb/>brown band over medial-cubital cross- vein; a broad, indistinct, clique, pale smoky brown, transverse band<tei:lb/>at somewhat distad of three-quarters length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus robust; a pair of massive flap-like processes situated one on either side of midline, each<tei:lb/>terminating anteriorly in a small acute point. Paramere robust; apex acutely rounded; dorsal process<tei:lb/>situated at midlength, greatly reduced; present only as a slight projection; dorsal surface subbasally with a<tei:lb/>curving posteriorly directed, hook-like secondary process; ventral and lateral surfaces subbasally with very<tei:lb/>numerous, tiny, tooth-like projections.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype cT, Brazil: Amazonas, P. das Laranjeiras, 28.vii.1981 (Arias) (INPA).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IPSEMYSIDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Ipsemysidia beautifica sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head in dorsal aspect greater than 1-5 times length. Vertex little longer than width at base,<tei:lb/>extending less than one-third its length beyond anterior margins of eyes; lateral margins not highly<tei:lb/>elevated, very gradually and regularly converging from base; basal margin shallowly concave; junction<tei:lb/>with frons weakly angulate. Frons c. 3 times as long as width at apex, c. twice width at base; lateral margins<tei:lb/>weakly diverging from apex to level of midline of eyes, then very strongly diverging to base. Genae<tei:lb/>extending anterior to eyes for c. half horizontal diameter of eye. Second antennal segment c. 1-5 times as<tei:lb/>long as broad, rounded; flagellum arising subapically. Ocelli distinct, not prominent. Clypeus short,<tei:lb/>broadly rounded, little longer than frons; medial and lateral carinae obsolete or absent. Rostrum not<tei:lb/>extending beyond hind coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width less than 10 times mid-dorsal length; dorsal surface little constricted medially; fronto-<tei:lb/>lateral surfaces each with a somewhat sinuate carina extending horizontally from adjacent to midline of eye<tei:lb/>to lateral margin. Tegula not carinate. Disc of mesonotum considerably wider than long; medial carinae<tei:lb/>weak, lateral carinae absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen more than 6 mm long, c. 3 times maximum width. Fused radial and subcostal veins separating at<tei:lb/>c. midlength. Medial vein distinct from base, forking at c. midlength and two-thirds length, with seven<tei:lb/>branches extending to posterior and apical margins, first branch linked to cubital vein, second to third by<tei:lb/>cross-veins. Radial vein with two branches extending to apical margin, linked to medial by a cross- vein<tei:lb/>slightly distad of two-thirds length. Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin, first and<tei:lb/>second, and third and fourth linked by cross-veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of wing more than half that of tegmen, c. twice maximum width; apex acutely rounded. Subcostal<tei:lb/>and radial veins fused from base to c. midlength, unbranched; radial linked to medial vein by a cross-vein<tei:lb/>slightly distad of two-thirds length. Medial vein with two branches extending to post-apical margin, linked<tei:lb/>to cubital by a cross-vein at level of second fork of the latter. Cubital vein with three branches extending to<tei:lb/>posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus symmetrical, horizontal; dorsal surface heavily armed subapically,<tei:lb/>including a single process at midline. Paramere with dorsal process reduced; a hook-like secondary process<tei:lb/>on dorsal surface subbasally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Though resembling Neomysidia in the development of the paramere, Ipsemysidia is readily<tei:lb/>distinguished by external and aedeagal characters. It is recorded from Brazil and Panama.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 101</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ipsemysidia beautifies sp. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 8, 21, 26, 162, 166, 170)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-42 mm long, 0-65 mm wide; pronotum 1-50 mm wide; tegmen 6-00 mm long; wing 3-60 mm<tei:lb/>long. Female: tegmen 7-20 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons c. 3 times width at apex, c. twice width at base; ocelli distinct; clypeus c. as long as frons;<tei:lb/>rostrum terminating at level of mid-coxae. Pronotal width 7 times mid-dorsal length, fronto-lateral carinae<tei:lb/>very prominent; tegula not carinate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head unmarked. Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum basally reddish; abdomen with a small dark brown<tei:lb/>spot on either side of mid-dorsal line . Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline , veins yellow , cross-veins and forks<tei:lb/>of veins dark brown; posterior margin irregularly dark brown. Tegmen with branches of cubital vein and<tei:lb/>two basal branches of medial vein each with at least one small black tubercule at c. midlength; medial vein<tei:lb/>with apical forks blackish brown; branches of apical vein each with a small, circular, dark brown spot<tei:lb/>subapically; posterior branch of radial vein similarly marked; apical cells of radial and medial veins each<tei:lb/>with an irregular brownish spot medially at two-thirds length; area between radial vein and costal margin<tei:lb/>irregularly mottled brownish, these markings extending posteriorly over first forks of medial and cubital<tei:lb/>veins; clavus with a brown spot adjacent to point of fusion of anal veins, another smaller spot subapically.<tei:lb/>Wing with radial and medial branches each bearing a small black tubercule; medial vein basad of<tei:lb/>medial-cubital cross-vein with two to four similar tubercules; cubital vein with two tubercules between first<tei:lb/>and second forks, third branch occasionally with a single tubercule subbasally; a large, irregular, brownish<tei:lb/>spot between first branch of cubital vein and claval suture somewhat distad of base of former; an irregular,<tei:lb/>oblique, smoky brown band over radial and medial areas at five-sixths length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus bearing a pair of large, apically rounded, flap-like processes laterally, and a single,<tei:lb/>slender, curving, spine-like process medially; ventral surface with a pair of long, closely opposed, flap-like<tei:lb/>processes subapically. Paramere slender basally, broadly expanded towards regularly rounded apex;<tei:lb/>dorsal process situated at approximately three-quarters length, very weakly produced postero-dorsally;<tei:lb/>dorsal surface at one-quarter length with a large, posteriorly directed, hook-like secondary process; ventral<tei:lb/>surface subbasally with a group of long, robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>AMYSIDIELLA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Amysidiella micare sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of head in dorsal aspect half to three-quarters greater than length. Vertex extending for less than<tei:lb/>one-quarter its length beyond anterior margins of eyes; lateral margins elevated, gradually converging<tei:lb/>from base; basal margin transverse, very weakly concave; junction with frons broadly and regularly<tei:lb/>rounded. Length of frons c. 5 times width at apex, less than twice width at base; lateral margins gradually<tei:lb/>diverging from apex to level of ocelli, then strongly diverging to base. Genae extending anterior to eyes for<tei:lb/>less than one-third horizontal diameter of eye. Second antennal segment club-shaped, not longer than<tei:lb/>twice maximum width; flagellum arising subapically. Ocelli distinct, not prominent. Clypeus, short, broad,<tei:lb/>rounded; length c. equal to that of frons, 1-5 times width at base; lacking medial and lateral carinae.<tei:lb/>Rostrum not extending beyond hind-coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width 11-14 times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces each with a weak carina extending<tei:lb/>horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral margin. Tegula not carinate. Disc of mesonotum c. as wide as<tei:lb/>long; medial carina weak or obsolete; lateral carinae absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of tegmen 5-90-7-20 mm, slightly less than 3 times maximum width. Medial vein separating from<tei:lb/>fused radial and subcostal veins at c. one-sixth length; with seven branches extending to post-apical margin.<tei:lb/>Radial and subcostal veins fused over c. basal one-third length; radial with two branches extending to<tei:lb/>apical margin, linked to medial by cross-veins at slightly distad of second fork of the latter, and to subcostal<tei:lb/>subapically. Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin; first and second, and third and<tei:lb/>fourth linked by cross-veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of wing slightly greater than half that of tegmen; apex acutely rounded. Cubital vein with three<tei:lb/>branches extending to posterior margin, linked by a cross-vein to medial at level of second fork. Medial<tei:lb/>vein two-branched; linked to unbranched radial vein by a cross- vein at c. two-thirds length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body yellowish. Frons and genae at level of eyes reddish. Fronto-lateral surfaces of pronotum<tei:lb/>and ventro-lateral surfaces of mesonotum each with a distinct horizontal reddish band. Tegmen and wing</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>102 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>faintly whitish hyaline, veins pale, lacking prominent pigmentation. Tegmen with a brownish spot adjacent<tei:lb/>to costal margin subbasally; another darker irregular marking extending anteriorly from claval margin at c.<tei:lb/>one-third length. Wing either unmarked, or with a very faint, irregular transverse band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus horizontal, symmetrical, subapically expanded, robust in lateral<tei:lb/>aspect; dorsal and lateral surfaces with prominent spine-like processes; ventral surfaces unarmed.<tei:lb/>Paramere with dorsal process reduced to a small, posteriorly directed, hook-like projection subapically.<tei:lb/>Posterior margin of subgenital plate transverse. Anal tube strongly produced posteriorly, postero-lateral<tei:lb/>angles expanded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female with posterior margin of subgenital plate regularly produced, apically truncate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amysidiella is distinguished by a combination of the proportions of the head, pronotum, legmen<tei:lb/>and wing, and by the structure of the male genitalia, consisting of a very heavily armed aedeagus<tei:lb/>with a paramere in which the dorsal process is almost obsolete. Recorded from Brazil and<tei:lb/>Guyana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Amysidiella</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Pronotum with maximum width in excess of 13 times length at mid-dorsal line. Aedeagus with</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral spines short, arising basad of mid-length (Fig. 164) micare sp. n. (p. 102)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotum with maximum width less than 12 times length at mid-dorsal line. Aedeagus with<tei:lb/>lateral spines very long, arising distad of mid-length (Fig. 163) pseudonucaresp. n. (p. 102)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amysidiella micare sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 4, 22, 25, 164, 167, 171)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male: head 0-40 mm long, 0-69 mm wide; pronotum 1-18 mm wide; tegmen 5-95-6-12 mm long; wing<tei:lb/>3-40 mm long. Female: tegmen 7-14 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of frons 5-5 times width at apex, 1-5 times width at base; ocelli small, distinct; clypeus as long as<tei:lb/>frons. Pronotal width 14 times mid-dorsal length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frons with a scarlet spot at level of eyes, often extending onto adjacent surfaces of genae. Pronto-lateral<tei:lb/>surfaces of pronotum each with a narrow scarlet band extending horizontally from level of ventral margin<tei:lb/>of eye to lateral margin; male with apices of posterior lobes of anal tube dark brown/black. Tegmen with a<tei:lb/>pale brownish spot between costal margin and point of separation of radial and subcostal veins; another<tei:lb/>larger, irregular marking at approximately one-third length extending from costal margin over first fork of<tei:lb/>cubital vein; an irregular band extending from apex of clavus to second branch of cubital vein. Wing with a<tei:lb/>very weak transverse band at level of medial-cubital cross-vein.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shaft of aedeagus broadly expanded over apical one-half length; lateral surfaces subapically each with a<tei:lb/>large, flap-like process terminating apically in a curving spine; dorsal surface at three-quarters length with a<tei:lb/>pair of small, curving, spines at midline, and laterally at rather over midlength, with a pair of long, slender,<tei:lb/>curving, spine-like processes. Paramere slender; dorsal process situated at three-fifths length, greatly<tei:lb/>reduced, consisting of a single, short, posteriorly directed, hooked spine; dorsal surface subbasally with a<tei:lb/>flap-like process bearing numerous long, robust spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype C?, Brazil: Belem, Para, v;1924 (Williams) (BMNH).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. Brazil: 2 cT, 1 9, same data as holotype (BMNH). Guyana: 4 cf , Blairmont (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is readily distinguished by its pigmentation, especially the dark posterior lobes of<tei:lb/>the anal tube in the male, and by the reduced armature of the paramere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amysidiella pseudomicaresp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TAXONOMY OF NEOTROPICAL DERBIDAE IN THE NEW TRIBE MYSIDIINI (HOMOPTERA) 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>point of separation of medial and fused radial-subcostal veins; a distinct, irregular, transverse, brownish<tei:lb/>band extending from costal margin over radial and medial veins at one-third length and terminating at base<tei:lb/>of third branch of cubital vein; an irregular, pale brownish spot extending from first-second cubital<tei:lb/>cross-vein to claval margin.          <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype d", Brazil: Rio Uapes, 5.iii (Roman) (NR).<tei:lb/>Paratype. 1 $, same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species, though closely related to micare, may be distinguished by the greater lateral<tei:lb/>expansion and the length, position and inclination of the spines of the aedeagus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARAM YSIDIA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Mysidia mississippiensis Dozier, by present designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head in dorsal aspect as wide as or up to one-third wider than long. Vertex extending beyond anterior<tei:lb/>margins of eyes for from one-third to one-half its length; lateral margins gradually converging from base to<tei:lb/>level of anterior margins of eyes, thence subparallel to apex; lateral carinae very prominent, almost<tei:lb/>foliaceous apically; basal margin shallowly concave; junction with frons broadly and regularly rounded.<tei:lb/>Frons c. 4-6 times as long as wide at apex, c. twice width at base; lateral margins subparallel from apex to<tei:lb/>level of ocelli, then gradually diverging to base, or very gradually and regularly diverging from apex and<tei:lb/>abruptly curving outwards subbasally. Genae extending beyond eyes for two-fifths to one-half horizontal<tei:lb/>diameter of eye. Antenna short; second segment club-shaped, c. twice as long as broad; apex weakly<tei:lb/>stepped; flagellum arising subapically. Ocelli commonly large, distinct; rarely prominent. Clypeus short,<tei:lb/>broadly rounded; length c. equal to that of frons, twice width at base; medial carina generally obsolete or<tei:lb/>absent; lateral carinae obsolete, or only distinct subbasally. Rostrum usually terminating immediately<tei:lb/>posterior to hind coxae, rarely extending to midlength of abdomen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pronotal width from 10-13 times mid-dorsal length; fronto-lateral surfaces each with a prominent carina<tei:lb/>curving horizontally from adjacent to eye to lateral margin. Tegula not carinate, or with carina obsolete.<tei:lb/>Disc of mesonotum slightly wider than long; medial carina often weak or obsolete, rarely distinct and<tei:lb/>percurrent; lateral carinae usually absent, rarely distinct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen commonly from 5 -00-6 -50 mm long, rarely exceeding 7-00 mm long. Medial vein distinct from<tei:lb/>near base, with seven branches extending to posterior and apical margins, second branch linked to third,<tei:lb/>and fourth to fifth by cross-veins. Fused radial and subcostal veins separating at c. midlength; radial with<tei:lb/>two branches extending to apical margin, linked to medial by a single cross-vein at two-thirds length.<tei:lb/>Cubital vein with four branches extending to posterior margin; first and second, and third and fourth linked<tei:lb/>by cross-veins.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of wing from three-fifths to three-quarters that of tegmen. Subcostal and radial veins fused over<tei:lb/>basal one-third length, unbranched. Radial vein linked to second fork of medial vein by a single cross-vein<tei:lb/>at two-thirds length. Medial vein with two branches extending to apical margin, linked to cubital vein by a<tei:lb/>cross-vein at two-thirds length. Cubital vein with three branches.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and body predominantly yellowish brown, often very pale; genae adjacent to ocelli often tinged<tei:lb/>reddish; pronotum with fronto-lateral surfaces often deep yellow over carinae; dorsal surface of abdomen<tei:lb/>rarely red or dark brown. Tegmen and wing whitish hyaline; veins yellowish or dark brown; cross- veins and<tei:lb/>forks of veins usually dark brown; veins and cross-veins often edged smoky brown, giving a mottled<tei:lb/>appearance. Tegmen rarely with an irregular, smoky brown, transverse band. Wing commonly with two<tei:lb/>weak, very irregular, smoky brown, transverse bands; posterior and apical margins often broadly pale<tei:lb/>brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with shaft of aedeagus slender, horizontal, cylindrical, somewhat laterally expanded<tei:lb/>subapically; dorsal surface subapically with a pair of very asymmetrical, dorsally directed, longitudinally<tei:lb/>aligned processes, of which that on the right is flap-like, that on the left commonly slender and spine-like;<tei:lb/>dorsal surface at c. midlength with a single, usually slender, dorsally directed, apically bifid secondary</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>104 PETER S. BROOMFIELD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apodeme medially; lateral margins often each with an antero-laterally directed apically bifid process at c.<tei:lb/>midlength; ventral surface unarmed. Paramere commonly with apex broadly rounded; dorsal process<tei:lb/>situated subapically, greatly reduced; dorsal surface subbasally with a small hook-like secondary process;<tei:lb/>rarely with apex acute or dorsal process robust. Anal tube not greatly extended, apex commonly notched<tei:lb/>medially.<tei:lb/>Female with posterior margin of subgenital plate frequently produced medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paramysidia differs from Mysidia as follows: the armature of the aedeagus is strongly asymmet-<tei:lb/>rical and includes a prominent process at midlength on the mid-dorsal line; the development of<tei:lb/>the dorsal process of the paramere is usually strongly reduced, its function possibly being, at<tei:lb/>least partially, taken over by the hook-like secondary process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distributed from the U.S.A. (Mississippi, Florida, Texas, Louisiana) to Costa Rica, Hon-<tei:lb/>duras, El Salvador, Panama, Brazil and Peru. From this distribution it would appear that species<tei:lb/>of the genus probably reached the U.S. A. via Central America, though it has not been recorded<tei:lb/>from Mexico. This shows a marked contrast with Dysimia, which almost certainly found its way<tei:lb/>into North America by island-hopping across the Caribbean.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Paramysidia (based on external characters)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Due to the extreme external similarity of many species, reference should be made, where possible, to the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>structure of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Tegmen with cross- veins and forks of veins not distinctly margined smoky brown. South-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>easternU.S.A mississippiensis (Dozier)(p. 105)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen with cross-veins and forks of veins broadly margined smoky brown 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2(1) Tegmen with veins yellowish or pale brown 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tegmen with veins dark brown 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3(2) Clypeus with length less than that of f rons ; genae often tinged orange ; f ronto-lateral surfaces</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of pronotum with carinae orange. Peru vulgaris sp. n. (p. 106)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus with length equal to that of frons; head and body unmarked. Brazil .... felix sp. n. (p. 106)<tei:lb/>4(2) Clypeus with length not greater than that of frons; frons with length less than 5 times width at</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apex 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus with length one-third greater than that of frons; frons with length almost 6 times</tei:p>
         <tei:p>width at apex. Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador barbara sp. n. (p. 106)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5(4) Width of pronotum 11 times length at mid-dorsal line 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Width of pronotum greater than 13 times length at mid-dorsal line. Panama boudica sp. n. (p. 107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6(5) Rostrum extending to mid-length of abdomen. Costa Rica tessellatasp. n.(p. 107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rostrum terminating immediately posterior to hind coxae. Costa Rica, Panama</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nigropunctata (Metcalf) (p. 105)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Paramysidia (based on male genitalia)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Paramere with dorsal process strongly reduced 2</tei:p>

         <tei:p>2(1) Paramere with apex broadly rounded 3</tei:p>

         <tei:p>4(3) Aedeagus with right dorsal process slender , distinctly longer than broad 5</tei:p>
