Importantly, several samples contain both individuals with<tei:lb/>obvious small pores and those with such small pores not evident, and D. perseae is regarded as a<tei:lb/>junior synonym of decempuncta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The samples of decempuncta from Breynia in New Guinea exhibit a further variation, which is<tei:lb/>very confusing when encountered in its most extreme form - a tendency to lose the 5 pairs of<tei:lb/>large simple subdorsal pores which are the principal diagnostic feature of the genus. One sample<tei:lb/>each from Lasanga Island and Buso contains individuals which vary from those lacking the 5<tei:lb/>pairs of pores to those with the pores all present but small, and individuals from two further Buso<tei:lb/>samples all lack pores. The remainder of the morphological characters, particularly the short<tei:lb/>lanceolate setae in the submargin and the shape and size of the vasiform orifice and lingula, are<tei:lb/>typical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The samples from ^.Breynia (Wau) and Glochidion (Buso) have normally developed large<tei:lb/>pores and submarginal setae, but have unusually long first and eighth abdominal, caudal and<tei:lb/>cephalic setae - longer than the width of the vasiform orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material from Tonga (BMNH), identified as decempuncta and listed in Mound &amp; Halsey,<tei:lb/>does not match even the variants described here and should be regarded as belonging to an<tei:lb/>unidentified species of Dialeuropora.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Austro-Oriental Region: Java, Papua New Guinea, Sarawak, Singapore, West<tei:lb/>Malaysia. Oriental Region: Cambodia, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand. Pacific<tei:lb/>Region: New Caledonia. Australasian Region: Northern Territory.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papua New Guinea: Buso, on Alphitonia sp. (Rhamnaceae), Breynia sp. (Euphorbiaceae), Colocasia<tei:lb/>c.v. (Araceae), Glochidion (Euphorbiaceae), Macaranga sp. (Euphorbiaceae), Pometia pinnata tree<tei:lb/>crown (Sapindaceae), Tetracera sp. (Dilleniaceae) and undetermined host; Lasanga Island, on Breynia<tei:lb/>sp., Macaranga sp., Pterocarpus tindicus (Leguminosae) and ?Leguminosae; Wau Ecology Institute, on<tei:lb/>? Breynia sp. (all BMNH). Java: Jakarta, on Musa sp. (Musaceae) and Psidium guajava (Myrtaceae)<tei:lb/>(BMNH). Sarawak: Gunung Mulu National Park, on IMillettia sp. (Leguminosae) and undetermined<tei:lb/>hosts (all BMNH). Singapore: on fEugenia sp. (Myrtaceae) (BMNH). West Malaysia: Taman Negara<tei:lb/>National Park, Kuala Tahan, on Flemingia macrophylla (Leguminosae) and undetermined hosts; Tioman<tei:lb/>Island, on Bauhinia sp. vine (Leguminosae) and ?Leguminosae (all BMNH). New Caledonia: Dothio<tei:lb/>River bridge (paratypes of Dialeurodes dothioensis Dumbleton, F. Cohic. coll. , synonymised by Mound &amp;<tei:lb/>Halsey, 1978), on undetermined host (BMNH). Australia: Northern Territory, on Eucalyptus sp.<tei:lb/>(Myrtaceae) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INDOALEYRODES David &amp; Subramaniam</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indoaleyrodes David &amp; Subramaniam, in Krishnamurthy, Raman &amp; David, 1973: 75. Type-species:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indoaleyrodes pustulatus David &amp; Subramaniam, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Indoaleyrodes David &amp; Subramaniam, 1976: 199.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The name Indoaleyrodes pustulatus was first published in an account of the feeding damage to<tei:lb/>leaves ofMorinda tinctoria (Rubiaceae) (Krishnamurthy, Raman &amp; David, 1973, quoting David<tei:lb/>&amp; Subramaniam, 1972). The 1972 reference was given as 'Studies on some Indian Aleyrodidae<tei:lb/>(in press), Mem. zool. Surv. India, Calcutta' which in fact appeared, in a different journal, in<tei:lb/>1976. Although a description of the work of an animal constitutes an 'indication' for the<tei:lb/>purposes of Article 25 of the Code, the definitive description of /. pustulatus appears in David &amp;<tei:lb/>Subramaniam (1976), and the 'holotype' and 'paratypes' must properly be regarded as syntypes<tei:lb/>(3 in BMNH [examined]).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>/. pustulatus is considered a junior synonym (syn. n.) of Dialeurodes laos Takahashi (1942),<tei:lb/>and laos is here included in Indoaleyrodes (comb. n.).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>328 J. H. MARTIN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indoaleyrodes differs from Dialeurodes primarily in its deeply indented thoracic and caudal<tei:lb/>tracheal pores, combined with a triangular vasiform orifice in which the operculum does not<tei:lb/>occupy most of its area as in Dialeurodes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition to laos and pseudoculatus (see below), it is clear that Parabemisia reticulata<tei:lb/>Dumbleton (19610) should also be included in Indoaleyrodes (comb. n.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indoaleyrodes pseudoculatus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 20, 21)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Outline almost circular, only 1-15-1-25 times longer than wide, widest opposite hind legs,<tei:lb/>margin indented slightly at thoracic and caudal tracheal openings, but with actual tracheal pores inset from<tei:lb/>main marginal outline by about 3 times pore diameter (Fig. 20). Apparently sexually dimorphic, with<tei:lb/>dimensions in the ranges 1-34-1-41 mm by 1-15-1-21 mm and 1-03-1-09 mm by 0-86-0-90 mm. Margin<tei:lb/>smooth and slightly irregular, with single pairs of short, fine anterior and posterior marginal setae. Cuticle<tei:lb/>pale, transparent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Closely set parallel lines run mesad from margin into outer subdorsum, length of these lines a<tei:lb/>little greater than distance from main marginal outline to tracheal pores (Fig. 20, inset). Thorax bearing a<tei:lb/>pair of very prominent oval glandular areas with polygonal reticulate pattern, resembling compound eyes;<tei:lb/>each patch situated about mid-way between thoracic tracheal pore and legs, and a little longer than<tei:lb/>vasiform orifice. A pair of comma-shaped patches of similar appearance adjacent to vasiform orifice,<tei:lb/>similar in length to orifice (Fig. 21). Remainder of dorsal surface smooth, with a few scattered tiny disc<tei:lb/>pores. Moulting sutures rather faint, not apparently reaching margin. Median length of abdominal<tei:lb/>segment VII about half that of segment VI . Dorsal disc not defined . Only 3 pairs of dorsal setae present , all<tei:lb/>fine and rather short, cephalic and caudal pairs hardly longer than diameter of tracheal pore: cephalic setae<tei:lb/>placed at level of apices of front legs; eighth abdominal setae lateral to anterior edge of vasiform orifice;<tei:lb/>caudal setae slightly anterolaterad of caudal tracheal pore. Vasiform orifice (Fig. 21) large, triangular,<tei:lb/>1-15-1-25 times longer than wide, inset from posterior margin of case by about 1-5-2-0 times its own length;<tei:lb/>posterior part of internal margin of vasiform orifice produced into a squared process with width similar to<tei:lb/>diameter of head of lingula. Caudal furrow not marked. Operculum rounded-trapezoidal, occupying basal<tei:lb/>half of vasiform orifice. Lingula long and stout, head developed into a spinulose club with a pair of basal<tei:lb/>lateral lobes and an apical pair of long spines which overlap apex of vasiform orifice; lingula exposed but<tei:lb/>included within vasiform orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Caudal and thoracic tracheal folds marked by small groups of coarse spinules running mesad in<tei:lb/>widening bands from the pores (Fig. 20) ; caudal fold achieving width of vasiform orifice at level of posterior<tei:lb/>abdominal spiracle, and thoracic folds achieving similar maximum width. A short spine present at base of<tei:lb/>each middle and hind leg. Mouthparts well developed, with distinct aphid-like ultimate rostral segment<tei:lb/>of similar length (longitudinal axis) to operculum. Ventral abdominal setae similar to dorsal eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Morobe Province coast, Buso, on tree-crown foliage of<tei:lb/>Syzygium sp. (Myrtaceae), S.x.1979 (/. H. Martin 2674) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 13 pupal cases, 1 larva, same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is known from a single collection from young crown leaves of a 26-metre<tei:lb/>high tree of a Syzygium sp., reached from a walkway in the forest canopy. The pupae were not<tei:lb/>attended by ants, and no adults were found. The genus Indoaleyrodes is very little known, so no<tei:lb/>speculation may be made about the likely host range of this remarkable new species. At least two<tei:lb/>of the specimens were parasitized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>/. pseudoculatus is at once separated from the other described species by the remarkable<tei:lb/>glandular areas on the cephalothorax, which resemble compound eyes, and by the comma-<tei:lb/>shaped glandular areas on each side of the vasiform orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two pupal cases which closely resemble pseudoculatus are present in the BMNH collection<tei:lb/>(Indoaleyrodes sp. 2, p. 307). One is incomplete and the second evidently damaged by a fungus<tei:lb/>before it was collected. They differ from pseudoculatus in having the abdominal glandular areas<tei:lb/>fused to form a U-shape, which starts anterior to the vasiform orifice and crosses the caudal<tei:lb/>furrow half-way between the orifice and the caudal pore; they also differ in the shape and<tei:lb/>position of the vasiform orifice. They were collected from an undetermined host at 6,000 ft in the<tei:lb/>Kampere Barola Divide.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE WHITEFLY OF NEW GUINEA 329</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Another species of Indoaleyrodes (sp. 1, p. 307) is represented by a single pupal case from<tei:lb/>Celtis philippinensis (Ulmaceae), but this possesses neither cephalothoracic nor abdominal<tei:lb/>glandular areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOMASKELLIA Quaintance &amp; Baker<tei:lb/>Neomaskellia Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1913: 91. Type-species: Aleurodes comata Maskell, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neomaskellia bergii (Signoret)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 38)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleurodes bergii Signoret, 1868: 395. Syntype pupal cases, MAURITIUS (depository unknown).<tei:lb/>Neomaskellia bergii (Signoret) Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1914: 104.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Papua New Guinea; also widely distributed throughout Africa, the Orient, South<tei:lb/>East Asia and the Pacific Region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papua New Guinea: Lasanga Island, on Saccharum ? officinarum (Gramineae), attended by ants<tei:lb/>(Oecophylla smaragdina); Bubia (Lae), on Saccharum officinarum and Cenchrus ciliaris (Gramineae); Pig<tei:lb/>Island (Madang), on Saccharum officinarum; Amax mining camp (Hessen Bay, Morobe Province), on<tei:lb/>undetermined grass (all BMNH); Wau, on undetermined grass (BMNH; BPBM); Laloki, on undeter-<tei:lb/>mined grass (BMNH; BPBM); 'Papua', on Saccharum sp. (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ORCHAMOPLA TVS Russell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleuroplatus (Orchamus) Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1917: 400. Type-species: Aleuroplatus (Orchamus)<tei:lb/>mammaeferus Quaintance &amp; Baker, by monotypy. [Homonym of Orchamus Stal, 1876: 30 (Orthop-<tei:lb/>tera).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orchamus Quaintance &amp; Baker; Dumbleton, 1956: 13 [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orchamoplatus Russell, 1958: 390. [Replacement name for Orchamus Quaintance &amp; Baker.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since Russell (1958) revised the genus, with 10 included species, a further three, dumbletoni<tei:lb/>(Cohic, 1959), perdentatus Dumbleton (19610) and sudaniensis Gameel (1968), have been<tei:lb/>described. As sudaniensis does not possess submarginal glands of the dentate type characteristic<tei:lb/>of Orchamoplatus, it should be included in Neoaleurotrachelus Takahashi &amp; Mamet [synony-<tei:lb/>mous v/ithJeannelaleyrodes Cohic (Bink-Moenen, 1983)] (comb, n.); this opinion was expressed<tei:lb/>to Gameel by Mound (pers. comm. , 1967) prior to publication of the description.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orchamoplatus niuginiisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 22, 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Completely pale to slightly dusky, ovoid, rather large: 0-85-1-25 mm long, 0-59-0-87 mm<tei:lb/>wide, mostly 1-4-1-5 times as long as wide, widest at abdominal segment II. Margin irregularly crenulate,<tei:lb/>about 13-15 small, rounded crenulations to 0- 1 mm of abdominal margin, with fine folds running mesad for<tei:lb/>a short distance from the bases of the crenulations (Fig. 23). Margin much indented at regions of thoracic<tei:lb/>and caudal tracheal openings, marginal crenulations very strongly differentiated to form thoracic and<tei:lb/>caudal tracheal combs. Usual pairs of anterior and posterior marginal setae present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Submargin with single row of evenly spaced dentate glands (the term 'gland' used by Russell,<tei:lb/>1958), 50-70 pairs in total, with 16-20 pairs anterior to thoracic combs and 38-50 pairs posteriorly (Fig. 22);<tei:lb/>structure of glands as in Fig. 23. Row of submarginal dentate glands mostly inset from margin by 3-4 times<tei:lb/>length of gland crown, although row of glands and margin converge at tracheal regions. Dentate glands<tei:lb/>adjacent to thoracic and caudal combs not different to remaining glands, not reaching margin. Thoracic<tei:lb/>and caudal tracheal combs well developed, set in deep marginal concavities, with fluted areas at the tooth<tei:lb/>bases extending mesad of the line of dentate glands; thoracic combs normally with 10 or 11 teeth, caudal<tei:lb/>comb with 8-10 teeth, combs evidently arched dorsally. Seven pairs of tiny submarginal setae present, 3<tei:lb/>cephalic, 2 thoracic and 2 mid-abdominal; the line of these setae completed by minute, evenly spaced<tei:lb/>porettes. Most specimens with pronounced cephalothoracic fold parallel to margin between submargin and<tei:lb/>subdorsum, fold extending posteriorly half-way to thoracic combs and then fading gradually. Longitudinal<tei:lb/>moulting suture not reaching margin of pupal case, terminating at cephalothoracic fold; transverse</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>330 J. H. MARTIN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>moulting sutures terminating in outer subdorsum. Dorsal cuticle mesad of dentate glands virtually smooth,<tei:lb/>punctuated only by very fine transverse lines of spinulose sculpturing on median part of abdominal<tei:lb/>segments II- VII, by coarser spinulose corrugations on median part of abdominal segment VIII (Fig. 23),<tei:lb/>and by an evenly spinulose patch on abdominal segment I (Fig. 22). Single pairs of cephalic, first and eighth<tei:lb/>abdominal setae present; cephalic and eighth abdominal pairs fine, cephalic pair the shorter; pair of setae<tei:lb/>on abdominal segment I in form of thick, chitinous spatulas which are often lost in preparation for<tei:lb/>slide-mounting. Disc pores well developed, about 12 pairs distributed as shown in Fig. 22. Vasiform orifice<tei:lb/>(Fig. 23) elevated and thus liable to distortion in slide-mounted specimens, subcircular, inner walls vertical<tei:lb/>with parallel vertical ridges; orifice about 60 ^im in diameter, usually appearing slightly wider than long,<tei:lb/>and inset a little more than its own length from posterior margin of pupal case (measured from apex of<tei:lb/>caudal tracheal comb). Operculum subtrapezoidal, almost filling cross-sectional area of vasiform orifice.<tei:lb/>Lingula shorter than vasiform orifice, head obscured by operculum, apparently rather square and densely<tei:lb/>spinulose. Caudal setae very long and fine, up to 0-21 mm long, bases situated just mesad of line of dentate<tei:lb/>glands, on inner border of caudal comb area. Caudal furrow not marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Thoracic and caudal tracheal folds virtually unmarked. A minute conical spine present at base of<tei:lb/>each middle and hind leg. Median parts of abdominal segments II-VIII very finely spinulose. Bases of<tei:lb/>ventral abdominal setae near anterior edge of vasiform orifice. Rostral base setae tiny, smaller than<tei:lb/>leg-base spines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Morobe Province coast, Lasanga Island, on Calophyllum<tei:lb/>inophyllum (Guttiferae), 18.ix.1979 (J. H. Martin 2581) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Papua New Guinea: 47 pupal cases, 1 larva, same data as holotype; 30 pupal cases, Morobe<tei:lb/>Province coast, Buso, same host, 30. ix. 1979 (JHM 2643); 19 pupal cases, 3 larvae, Lasanga Island, same<tei:lb/>host, 7.xi.l979 (JHM 2816); 3 pupal cases, 1 larva, Buso, on Durandea sp. (Linaceae) at canopy level,<tei:lb/>8.X.1979 (JHM 2676) (BMNH; USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The species occurs in very dense colonies on the underside of mature leaves of<tei:lb/>littoral Calophyllum inophyllum (Guttiferae), and is not attended by ants. These dense<tei:lb/>aggregations of pupae and larvae are covered with a glassy, translucent secretion which becomes<tei:lb/>hard when specimens are stored dry; folding the leaf then causes flakes of secretion to peel away<tei:lb/>with the insects embedded in it. The earlier larval exuviae often remain attached to the dorsa of<tei:lb/>the later stages, and sometimes all instars are represented in a stack. No adults were found and<tei:lb/>there was no sign of empty cases from which adults had emerged. A few specimens were also<tei:lb/>taken from a leaf of a species of Durandea vine in the forest canopy, but this provides the only<tei:lb/>firm evidence of oligophagy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. niuginii is similar to mammaeferus (Quaintance &amp; Baker) and montanus (Dumbleton), but<tei:lb/>differs from both in the following characteristics: submarginal dentate glands further inset from<tei:lb/>margin (3-4 times length of gland crown, compared with up to twice); dentate glands adjacent to<tei:lb/>both thoracic and caudal combs not larger than remainder of glands, not reaching margin of<tei:lb/>case; generally a larger species, pupal cases mostly over 1-0 mm long. O. niuginii further differs<tei:lb/>from mammaeferus in the possession of a pair of cephalic setae. O. niuginii bears no close<tei:lb/>resemblance to calophylli Russell, which was described from a species of Calophyllum in Tonga.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A further colony of Orchamoplatus at Buso was taken from a tree-crown leaf, possibly<tei:lb/>belonging to a species of Lophopetalum (Celastraceae). The mounted specimens agree with<tei:lb/>niuginii in most respects, but differ in the apparent shape of the vasiform orifice, and in<tei:lb/>possessing less-indented thoracic and caudal tracheal areas (apices of centre teeth in combs<tei:lb/>stand proud of margin of case). A field note states that all were parasitised, appearing black, and<tei:lb/>the venters failed to detach from the leaf. The mounted specimens, with parasites removed, are<tei:lb/>pale but ventrally incomplete; they are possibly morphologically modified by the parasites and<tei:lb/>are tentatively determined as niuginii.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARABEMISIA Takahashi<tei:lb/>ParabemisiaTakahashi, 1952: 21. Type-species: Parabemisia maculata Takahashi, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Takahashi (1952) erected Parabemisia to accommodate his new species maculata, Bemisia aceris<tei:lb/>Takahashi and Bemisia myricae Kuwana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dumbleton (1961a) assigned his species reticulata to Parabemisia on the basis of its laterally</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE WHITEFLY OF NEW GUINEA 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bilobed lingula head, while noting that other characters were not typical of the genus; reticulata<tei:lb/>is here transferred to Indoaleyrodes David &amp; Subramaniam (1973) (comb. n.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The five species currently placed in Parabemisia are keyed below, in a modified version of<tei:lb/>Takahashi's original key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Parabemisia<tei:lb/>Pupal cases</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Submarginal setae very short, sometimes hardly recognisable, numbering 11 pairs (excluding</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anterior and posterior marginal pairs and caudal pair). Head of lingula rather triangular,<tei:lb/>evenly tapering from near its base 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Submarginal setae long and conspicuous , subequal in length to vasiform orifice and caudal setae ,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>normally numbering 11 or 13 pairs (excluding anterior and posterior marginal pairs and caudal<tei:lb/>pair) . Head of lingula rather ovoid , not tapering evenly from near its base 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Head of lingula slender, over twice as long as wide; vasiform orifice elongated, caudal furrow</tei:p>
         <tei:p>distinct and slender ; tracheal folds (ventral) with fine dots aceris (Takahashi)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Head of lingula not slender, rather abruptly tapering; vasiform orifice not elongated, caudal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>furrow not well defined , but wider ; tracheal folds without fine dots maculata Takahashi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Submargin normally with 1 1 pairs of setae (excluding caudal pair) . Dorsum bearing many large ,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tubercular pores, each of which is about half as wide as operculum jawani sp. n. (p. 331)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Submargin normally with 13 pairs of setae (excluding caudal pair). Dorsum not bearing large,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tubercular pores 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Usually entirely pale, very occasionally with slight duskiness. Vasiform orifice with lateral</tei:p>
         <tei:p>margins straight or slightly concave myricae (Kuwana)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Never entirely pale , always with submargin and subdorsum brown . Vasiform orifice subcordate ,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral margins markedly convex, thickened myrmecophtia sp. n. (p. 332)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parabemisia jawani sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 24, 25)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Pale, oval, 0-8-1-1 mm long, broadest at abdominal segment III, 1-2-1-4 times as long as wide.<tei:lb/>Posterior margin flattened but hardly indented, without marginal indentation towards thoracic tracheal<tei:lb/>areas. Margin bluntly and rather unevenly crenulate, with about 12 teeth occupying 0-1 mm of margin.<tei:lb/>Thoracic and caudal tracheal openings each marked by a simple notch which is hardly wider than one<tei:lb/>marginal tooth (Fig. 25). Posterior marginal setae present, but anterior pair apparently lacking.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Twelve pairs of Submarginal setae present, 6 on cephalothorax and 6 on abdomen, including<tei:lb/>caudal pair; setae fine, a little longer than vasiform orifice, their bases situated just mesad of marginal<tei:lb/>teeth. A pair of tiny hairs present on each of abdominal segments I and VIII, but cephalic pair absent.<tei:lb/>Dorsum punctuated by evenly distributed, large, circular tubercular pores, each about half of opercular<tei:lb/>width in diameter, and with a paler central opening in stained specimens (Fig. 24). Median line of abdomen<tei:lb/>devoid of these pores, with evenly staining cuticle. Remainder of dorsal cuticle smooth, but staining picks<tei:lb/>out variations in sclerotisation which appear as irregular polygonal plates delineated by paler lines. Median<tei:lb/>lengths of abdominal segments I- VI subequal, but that of segment VII much reduced. Median lengths of<tei:lb/>meso- and metathoracic segments also subequal. Both transverse and longitudinal moulting sutures<tei:lb/>reaching margin, the dorsal halves of cephalothorax easily becoming detached. Vasiform orifice (Fig. 25)<tei:lb/>rounded-triangular to trapezoidal, with posterior margin abruptly truncated although not marked by a<tei:lb/>sharp line; orifice inset from posterior margin by about 3 times its own length; internal walls of orifice<tei:lb/>smooth, not notched. Operculum laterally-rounded trapezoidal, occupying about two-thirds of vasiform<tei:lb/>orifice. Lingula exposed, only just included in orifice; head dark, finely spinulose, with a pronounced pair<tei:lb/>of lateral processes ; apical setae not apparent. Caudal furrow well marked by a line of darkly staining spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Caudal and thoracic tracheal folds marked by bands of fine dots running mesad from margin,<tei:lb/>reaching vasiform orifice and outer edges of legs respectively (Fig. 25). A minute conical spine present at<tei:lb/>base of each middle and hind leg. Ventral abdominal setae long, fine, about as long as vasiform orifice.<tei:lb/>Abdominal spiracles close to ventral abdominal setae, appearing claw-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Morobe Province coast, Jawani Island, on undetermined<tei:lb/>woody host, 2.xi.l979 (J. H. Martin 2789) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype pupal cases. 16, same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>332 J. H. MARTIN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Nothing is known about the biology of this insect, which was encountered only once<tei:lb/>feeding on an undetermined woody host alongside mangroves on a small offshore island. The<tei:lb/>pupae were not attended by ants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. jawani is very distinctive with its large dorsal tubercular pores, and can be separated by the<tei:lb/>characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parabemisia myrmecophila sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 26, 27)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Outline rather pear-shaped, 0-65-0-90 mm long, 0-45-0-62 mm wide, broadest at abdominal<tei:lb/>segment III, mostly 1-4-1-5 times as long as wide. Brown, with variable median area pale, ranging from<tei:lb/>individuals which are almost evenly brown to those with whole of submedian area of dorsal disc pale; pale<tei:lb/>area widest on cephalothorax (Fig. 26). Margin (Fig. 27) evenly crenulate, with about 20 rounded-<tei:lb/>triangular teeth occupying 0-1 mm of margin. Margin very gently indented towards thoracic area at point<tei:lb/>where a tracheal comb is slightly differentiated from remainder of marginal teeth; posterior margin of case<tei:lb/>rounded or flattened, but not indented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. A row of 14 pairs of submarginal setae present, including caudal pair, setal bases situated just<tei:lb/>mesad of marginal teeth; submarginal setae fine, similar in length to the single pairs of cephalic and first and<tei:lb/>eighth abdominal setae, subequal to length of vasiform orifice. Dorsal disc pores similar in size to setal<tei:lb/>bases, scattered evenly, with 4-5 pairs on each of abdominal segments III- VIII, and about 30 pairs on<tei:lb/>cephalothorax. Tiny disc porettes also present. Cuticle slightly wrinkled, with a few darker granular<tei:lb/>markings on the brown areas. Median length of abdominal segment VII much less than half that of segment<tei:lb/>VI, abdomen appearing 7-segmented along median line. Longitudinal and transverse moulting sutures<tei:lb/>reaching margin of case. Vasiform orifice (Fig. 27) rather large, nearly 0-1 times length of case, subcordate,<tei:lb/>posterolaterally much thickened with toothed inner margin, posterior margin rather flattened; orifice<tei:lb/>60-80 /u,m long and wide, situated 65-100 /um from posterior margin of case. Operculum trapezoidal, only<tei:lb/>about half filling orifice. Lingula shorter than vasiform orifice, exposed but included; lingula head<tei:lb/>spinulose, with an apical pair of setae which are longer than lingula head, bearing a pair of small lateral<tei:lb/>lobes at base of head, each lobe with a short seta. Caudal furrow discernible in most specimens, although<tei:lb/>marked to a rather variable degree.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Caudal and thoracic tracheal folds not defined. A minute conical spine at base of each middle and<tei:lb/>hind leg, hardly longer than its own basal width. Ventral abdominal setae fine, similar to posterior marginal<tei:lb/>setae, but situated under vasiform orifice and thus not easy to see. Rostral base setae relatively large, over<tei:lb/>half length of anterior marginal setae, fine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Morobe Province coast, Buso, on Cryptocarya sp.<tei:lb/>(Lauraceae), 27.ix.1979 (/. H. Martin 2629) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Papua New Guinea: 48 pupal cases, same data as holotype; 11 pupal cases, 7 larvae, Buso, on<tei:lb/>Anisoptera sp. (Dipterocarpaceae), 27. ix. 1979 (JHM 2626); 44 pupal cases, 4 larvae, Buso, on Macaranga<tei:lb/>sp. (Euphorbiaceae), 27. ix. 1979 (JHM 2627); 44 pupal cases, 1 larva, Buso, on Prunus sp. (Rosaceae),<tei:lb/>26.ix.1979 (JHM 2622) (BMNH; USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species was always found in very dense colonies on undersides of young leaves<tei:lb/>of small woody saplings growing on the forest floor. In each case, the colony was vigorously<tei:lb/>attended by ants, Rhoptromyrmex melleus (Emery) . In one case, adults were observed emerging<tei:lb/>and then congregating in groups on the very youngest leaves of the same plant, Cryptocarya sp.<tei:lb/>It seems likely that in this way the colony can keep pace with the growth of the plant while it<tei:lb/>remains suitable for colonisation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. myrmecophila may be distinguished from other described species of Parabemisia by<tei:lb/>characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PEAL/l/SQuaintance &amp; Baker<tei:lb/>Pealius Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1914: 99. Type-species: Aleyrodes maskelli Bemis, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are currently 28 species assigned to Pealius, and the genus is particularly difficult to<tei:lb/>define; typically, the vasiform orifice has a 'false' posterior margin, continuing posteriorly as a<tei:lb/>shallow depression which is distinct from the caudal furrow (Fig. 28).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Five species from New Guinea are assigned to the Pealius-group, and are listed with host data<tei:lb/>on p. 308.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE WHITEFLY OF NEW GUINEA 333</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHACHISPHORA Quaintance &amp; Baker</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dialeurodes (Rhachisphora) Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1917: 430. Type-species: Dialeurodes (Rhachisphora)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trilobitoides Quaintance &amp; Baker, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Rhachisphora Quaintance &amp; Baker; Takahashi, 1952: 22 [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition to the specimen tentatively identified as R. ardisiae (see below), two further samples<tei:lb/>have been studied from New Guinea (p. 308). Rhachisphora sp. 1 has an oval pupal case similar<tei:lb/>to ardisiae and some other species, differing markedly from the anteriorly flattened species of<tei:lb/>the trilobitoides-group; this sample was collected from tree-crown leaves of a Schefflera sp.<tei:lb/>(Araliaceae) in Buso forest. The second sample (Rhachisphora^., sp. 2) contains pupal cases<tei:lb/>which are almost circular and markedly convex: the rather wide submedian area is smooth and<tei:lb/>brownish; the submargin and outer subdorsum are pale; the inner subdorsal area comprises 2<tei:lb/>lateral, arcuate, imbricate zones which stain very deeply and which have about 20 radial 'spokes'<tei:lb/>leading into the submargin, forming a pronounced though highly unusual rhachis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(?) Rhachisphora ardisiae (Takahashi) comb. n.<tei:lb/>Dialeurodes ardisiae Takahashi, 1935: 50, fig. 35. Syntype pupal cases, TAIWAN (TARI).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This record is based upon a single specimen which has not been compared with the type-<tei:lb/>material; accordingly, the record should be regarded as tentative, but from the description it is<tei:lb/>clear that ardisiae should be placed in Rhachisphora, rather than in Dialeurodes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. (Papua New Guinea), Taiwan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Papua New Guinea: Buso, on undetermined host (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TETRALEURODES Cockerell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleyrodes (Tetraleurodes) Cockerell, 1902: 283. Type-species: Aleyrodes perileuca Cockerell, by original</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation.<tei:lb/>Tetraleurodes Cockerell; Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1914: 107 [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifty-seven species of whitefly are currently placed in Tetraleurodes, which is a difficult genus to<tei:lb/>define. Those from New Guinea that are assigned to the Tetraleurodes-group all have dark<tei:lb/>brown to black pupal cases, lack thoracic and caudal tracheal differentiation, and have the<tei:lb/>submarginal and subdorsal regions separated by a suture-like fold.<tei:lb/>The 9 species from New Guinea are listed with host data on p. 308.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIALEURODES Cockerell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleyrodes (Trialeurodes) Cockerell, 1902: 283. Type-species: Aleurodes pergandei Quaintance, by original</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation.<tei:lb/>Trialeurodes Cockerell; Quaitance &amp; Baker, 1915: xi [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trialeurodes vaporariorum (Westwood)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 29)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleyrodes vaporariorum Westwood, 1856: 852. Syntype pupal cases, adults, GREAT BRITAIN: England</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Westwood collection, thought to be part of type series, BMNH; UMO) [examined].<tei:lb/>Trialeurodes vaporariorum (Westwood) Quaintance &amp; Baker, 1914: 105.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Papua New Guinea; also very widely distributed throughout the world, although<tei:lb/>Oriental, Austro-Oriental and Australasian records are rather sparse.<tei:lb/>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papua New Guinea: Goroka, on 'squash' (Cucurbitaceae) (BMNH; BPBM); Aiyura, on Solanum<tei:lb/>lycopersicon (Solanaceae) (BMNH); Chimbu, on English potato (Solanaceae) (BMNH). Great Britain:<tei:lb/>no data, part of Westwood series (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>334 J. H. MARTIN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XENALEYRODES Takahashi<tei:lb/>Xenaleyrodes Takahashi, 1936: 113. Type-species: Xenaleyrodes artocarpi Takahashi, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Takahashi (1936) erected Xenaleyrodes for artocarpi from the Palau Islands (Caroline group).<tei:lb/>The genus is distinguished from Aleurocanthus by the characteristic tubiform submarginal<tei:lb/>spines which are much thicker in the basal two-thirds, by the absence of similar spines elsewhere<tei:lb/>on the pupal case and by the deflexed margin (see generic key, p. 309). From a study of the<tei:lb/>original description, and of material in the BMNH, it is clear that Neomaskellia eucalypti<tei:lb/>Dumbleton (1956) from Australia should also be placed in Xenaleyrodes (comb. n.).<tei:lb/>A key to the pupal cases of the five species currently placed in Xenaleyrodes is given below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Xenaleyrodes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pupal cases</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Submarginal tubiform spines distinctly curved in apical third, often abruptly angled through 90</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 35). Comb of differentiated teeth present at position of thoracic tracheal openings near</tei:p>
         <tei:p>margin (Fig. 36) 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Submarginal tubiform spines much narrowed in apical third , but generally straight (Figs 3 1 , 33) .<tei:lb/>No differentiated teeth in thoracic tracheal area.<tei:lb/>Posteriorly with a single pair of very long, stout setae 0-3-0-4 mm long 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Second cephalothoracic pair of submarginal tubiform spines set much closer to 1st pair than to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3rd pair. Thoracic tracheal combs normally with about 8 teeth 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All cephalothoracic submarginal tubiform spines evenly spaced. Thoracic tracheal combs<tei:lb/>normally with 4 teeth timonii sp. n. (p. 336)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Dorsal cuticle rather rough, reticulate-granular; posterior margin of vasiform orifice produced</tei:p>
         <tei:p>into a pointed process with a median notch; all abdominal submarginal tubiform spines evenly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spaced artocarpi Takahashi (p. 334)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Dorsal cuticle smooth; posterior margin of vasiform orifice smoothly rounded, not produced<tei:lb/>into a pointed process; posterior two pairs of abdominal submarginal tubiform spines set<tei:lb/>closer together than remaining 4 pairs. (Australia, Victoria) eucalypti (Dumbleton)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Submargin with single row of about 30 pairs of shorter (90 ju,m) tubiform spines, interspersed</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with about 9 pairs of fine hairs up to 0-25 mm long (Fig. 30) broughae sp. n. (p. 334)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Submargin with single row of 11 pairs of longer (up to 0-12 mm) tubiform spines, interspersed<tei:lb/>with 7 pairs of short, lanciform, spines 25-40 /A long (Fig. 33) irianicus sp. n. (p. 335)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenaleyrodes artocarpi Takahashi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenaleyrodes artocarpi Takahashi, 1936: 113, fig. 2. Syntype pupal cases, PALAU ISLANDS (TARI).<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION. Palau Islands (Caroline group), Papua New Guinea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Papua New Guinea: Buso, on Premna sp. (Verbenaceae) and IDecaspermum sp. (Myrtaceae) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenaleyrodes broughae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 30-32)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Jet black, opaque, with an agglomeration of white wax (see comments). Evenly oval,<tei:lb/>1-40-1-50 mm long, 1-00-1-10 mm wide, widest at abdominal segments I &amp; II. Cases rather deep, with<tei:lb/>margin mostly deflexed under dorsum in slide-mounted specimens: apparent margin is thus merely part of<tei:lb/>submarginal dorsum and is smooth. Region of true margin complex: true margin serrate-toothed, with<tei:lb/>venter having another 'false margin' of rounded crenulations of about 3 times width of true marginal teeth<tei:lb/>(Fig. 32).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Dorsal surface almost smooth, and in evenly bleached specimens only slight mottling evident,<tei:lb/>even median abdominal segmentation little marked. Immediately mesad of (dorsal to) true margin is a line<tei:lb/>of small tubercles which appear paler than rest of cuticle; inset a little further is a ring of about 30 pairs of<tei:lb/>short, stout, tubiform spines with expanded apices, interspersed with about 9 pairs of very long fine hairs,<tei:lb/>including caudal pair (Fig. 30). Tubiform spines about 90 /xm long, with basal two-thirds markedly swollen;<tei:lb/>fine submarginal hairs up to 0-25 mm long, the ring of spines and hairs appearing marginal owing to<tei:lb/>deflexing of true margin. Adjacent to caudal hairs, with bases a little further inset than submarginal ring of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE WHITEFLY OF NEW GUINEA 335</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tubiform spines, is a pair of remarkably stout setae, up to 0-4 mm long and much darker than dusky<tei:lb/>tubiform spines: it seems likely that these are modified tubiform spines. Single pairs of cephalic, first and<tei:lb/>eighth abdominal setae also present, as detailed in Fig. 30. Thoracic and abdominal tracheal openings not<tei:lb/>discernible. Small eyespots present, best seen in untreated specimens. Transverse moulting sutures<tei:lb/>reaching apparent margin, joined distally to longitudinal suture by a variably defined cephalothoracic fold<tei:lb/>running concentric to margin. Each thoracic segment with a single pair of subcircular depressions in cuticle.<tei:lb/>Vasiform orifice elevated, oval, with operculum occupying whole area of orifice and obscuring lingula;<tei:lb/>orifice inset from apparent margin by a little more than its own length; eighth abdominal setae arising from<tei:lb/>lateral extensions of vasiform orifice elevation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Thoracic and caudal tracheal folds not marked. Entire venter smooth, not stippled or otherwise<tei:lb/>punctuated. Usual ventral spiracles, setae, legs and antennae present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Southern Highlands Province, Eraue, on Citrus sp.<tei:lb/>(Rutaceae), 21.vii.1983 (E. J. Brough E630) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype pupal cases. Papua New Guinea: 40, same data as holotype (BMNH; USNM). Spirit-stored<tei:lb/>material with same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Known from a single collection from the Southern Highlands Province of Papua<tei:lb/>New Guinea, where it occurred as a densely populated colony on a few leaves of a mature orange<tei:lb/>tree growing in a coffee nursery. Each pupa has a thin plate of wax covering the median and<tei:lb/>subdorsal areas, the wax thickening into dense white curls which extend from the submarginal<tei:lb/>area to well beyond the edge of the pupa, obscuring the ring of tubiform spines and hairs. The<tei:lb/>pupae are apparently attached to the leaf by the part of the venter inside the crenulate 'false<tei:lb/>margin', with a ring of white wax separating the outer ring of the venter from the leaf lamella.<tei:lb/>The colony was not apparently attended by ants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pupal cases were exceptionally resistant to bleaching, and could only be bleached<tei:lb/>successfully by using a mixture of 880-volume ammonia and approximately 20-volume hydrogen<tei:lb/>peroxide. With this reagent, bleaching to an acceptable level occurs in only a few minutes,<tei:lb/>without use of heat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>X. broughae can be distinguished from the other described species of Xenaleyrodes by the<tei:lb/>characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenaleyrodes irianicus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 33)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Jet black, opaque, in groups under leaves of host. Oval, up to 1-05 mm long, 0-85 mm wide,<tei:lb/>widest at abdominal segment I. Cases deep, margin deflexed, obscured by dorsum in slide-mounted<tei:lb/>specimens. True margin crenulate, with about 12 teeth to 0-1 mm of margin; a row of tubercles of similar<tei:lb/>size immediately mesad of true margin gives margin the appearance of being double in some prepar-<tei:lb/>ations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Smooth, unicolourous to slightly mottled in slide-mounted bleached specimens; abdominal<tei:lb/>and thoracic segmentation only faintly marked. Submarginal (apparently marginal, owing to deflexion of<tei:lb/>true margin) ring of about 11 pairs of tubiform spines up to 0-12 mm long, interspersed with 6 or 7 pairs of<tei:lb/>lanceolate spines about 25-40 /im long, distributed as shown in Fig. 33. Caudally a pair of very long, stout<tei:lb/>spines (probably modified tubiform spines) up to 0-3 mm long, and a pair of fine caudal hairs about 0-15 mm<tei:lb/>long. Single pairs of cephalic, first and eighth abdominal setae present, as detailed in figure. Thoracic and<tei:lb/>abdominal tracheal openings not discernible. Eyespots present. Transverse moulting sutures reaching<tei:lb/>apparent margin, longitudinal suture not so. Vasiform orifice elevated, oval, with operculum completely<tei:lb/>obscuring lingula. Eighth abdominal setae arising from lateral extensions of vasiform orifice elevation.<tei:lb/>Whole of caudal and vasiform orifice area strikingly similar to that of A', broughae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Ventral characters entirely as in X. broughae, with the exception of characteristics of true margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Irian Jaya: Biak, on undetermined tree, 23. v. 1959 (T. C. Mad) (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype pupal cases. 14, same data as holotype (BMNH; BPBM); dry material on leaf, same data as<tei:lb/>holotype (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Each pupa of X. irianicus is surrounded and covered by a secretion which, in dried<tei:lb/>specimens at least, is translucent and glassy, not the more usual white wax. Exuviae of the earlier<tei:lb/>instars do not appear to remain attached to the dorsum of the pupa.<tei:lb/>X. irianicus is similar to broughae in having the submarginal ring of tubiform spines inter-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>336 J. H. MARTIN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spersed with a smaller number of simple hairs/spines. However, the tubiform spines are fewer<tei:lb/>and longer, and the simple spines are fewer and shorter in irianicus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A further species, Xenaleyrod.es sp. 1 (p. 308), is represented by three damaged pupal cases<tei:lb/>from an unidentified host from near Lake Trist, Kuper Range, Papua New Guinea -this appears<tei:lb/>to be most similar to irianicus, but the submarginal tubiform spines do not appear to be<tei:lb/>interspersed with lanceolate spines, and the posteriormost pair are not as long and stout as in<tei:lb/>irianicus, although longer than the remainder.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xenaleyrodes timonii sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 34-37)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PUPAL CASE. Jet black, opaque, with little waxy secretion evident. Pupal cases oval, up to 0-95 mm long,<tei:lb/>0-65 mm wide, widest at thoraco-abdominal suture. Cases rather deep, with submargin deflexed, folded<tei:lb/>under remainder of dorsum in slide-mounted specimens; the apparent margin is thus merely a part of the<tei:lb/>submarginal dorsum, and is smooth to irregular. True margin, at junction of dorsum and venter, smooth:<tei:lb/>apparent crenulate to serrate appearance in most specimens is due to an adjacent line of tiny tubercles (Fig.<tei:lb/>36), precise appearance dependent upon angle of tubercles to viewing axis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsum. Cuticle almost completely smooth, punctuated only by one row of tiny tubercles just mesad of<tei:lb/>(i.e. vertically above, in unmounted specimens) true margin, and by disc porettes, a row just mesad of<tei:lb/>submarginal tubiform spines, a few subdorsally, and also scattered between tubiform spines and true<tei:lb/>margin. Submargin with single row of 12 pairs of evenly spaced, very prominent tubiform spines (Figs<tei:lb/>34-37); tubiform spines of specimens in situ on leaf with basal half to two-thirds (about 70 jim) horizontal,<tei:lb/>the apical part much narrower and angled downwards (see comments) through 90, apices expanded,<tei:lb/>laciniate. Single pairs of cephalic and first and eighth abdominal setae present; first abdominal pair rather<tei:lb/>variable, with the extremes shown in Fig. 34. Caudal setae very long, fine, longer than other dorsal setae,<tei:lb/>sometimes as long as 0-2 mm. Eye spots not marked. Thoracic and abdominal tracheal furrows not marked,<tei:lb/>but combs distinct; thoracic combs (Fig. 36) normally with 4 rounded teeth, occasionally with 3 or 5, set<tei:lb/>distinctly mesad of (above) true margin, each tooth about half as wide as base of a submarginal tubiform<tei:lb/>spine; caudal comb similar, with about 6 teeth. Longitudinal and transverse moulting sutures not reaching<tei:lb/>true margin; transverse sutures reaching apparent margin, transverse and longitudinal sutures joined<tei:lb/>distally by a cephalothoracic suture. Vasiform orifice (Fig. 37) oval, elevated, produced posteriorly into a<tei:lb/>blunt process; orifice toothed posterolaterally on internal walls, a little longer than wide, inset from<tei:lb/>posterior margin of case by about half its own length, about 65-80 /AHI long, 60-70 /im wide, about 30-50<tei:lb/>fj,m from margin. Width of dorsal opening of orifice dependent upon degree of flattening in slide-mounted<tei:lb/>specimens, but evidently less than maximum internal width of orifice (Fig. 37), and often measuring less<tei:lb/>than width of operculum. Operculum rather small, trapezoidal, occupying only about half of internal<tei:lb/>cross-sectional area of vasiform orifice. Lingula short, finger-shaped, finely spinulose, exposed but<tei:lb/>included within vasiform orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Venter. Thoracic and caudal tracheal folds not marked. Most of venter densely stippled, stipples most<tei:lb/>marked in submargin, only absent from median area of thorax. Abdominal segmentation evident. Minute<tei:lb/>conical seta present at base of each middle and hind leg. A group of 5-7 short, 2- or 3-pointed anchor spines<tei:lb/>present near anterior edge of venter, presumably to aid adhesion to leaf.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype pupal case, Papua New Guinea: Morobe Province coast, Buso, on Timonius sp. (Rubiaceae),<tei:lb/>10.ix.1979 (/. H. Martin 2527) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype pupal cases. Papua New Guinea: (all from same general locality and same host species) 26,<tei:lb/>same data as holotype; 19, riverside, 13.ix.1979 (JHM 2552, 2556); 28, riverside, 13.X.1979 (JHM 2691,<tei:lb/>2696); 5, beach-top, 12.X.1979 (/HM2687A); 25, beach-top, 6.ix.l979 (JHM25QQ) (BMNH; USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Known from seven samples, always from leaves of a species of Timonius growing on<tei:lb/>gravel bars between meanders of the fast-flowing Buso river, or in beach-top sand. The pupae<tei:lb/>occur in dense groups and are not attended by ants. The larval exuviae often remain attached to<tei:lb/>the dorsa of later stages, sometimes with all stages present in a stack. The species was never<tei:lb/>encountered on other hosts, and the name timonii appears appropriate. No adults were seen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>X. timonii may be distinguished from other Xenaleyrodes species by characters given in the<tei:lb/>key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Takahashi's original description of X. artocarpi (1936), the submarginal tubular spines are<tei:lb/>described as being 'eminently curved upward on the distal part'. It has not been possible to<tei:lb/>examine type-material of artocarpi, but specimens from New Guinea, identified as artocarpi by</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE WHITEFLY OF NEW GUINEA 337</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the author, clearly have down-curved spines as in timonii, and Takahashi's statement is, in all<tei:lb/>probability, an error of visual interpretation.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Addendum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>While this manuscript was in press four samples of Orchamoplatus mammaeferus (Quaintance &amp; Baker,<tei:lb/>1917: 400), collected in New Guinea, were received. O. mammaeferus is similar to niuginii, and the<tei:lb/>differences between the two species are discussed on p. 330.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papua New Guinea: near Laiagam and near Wabag, on Phaseolus vulgaris (Leguminosae) ; Wau, on<tei:lb/>Croton sp. (Euphorbiaceae); Mt Hagen, on sweet potato (Convolvulaceae) (all BMNH).<tei:lb/>This brings the total of named species (p. 304) to 38.</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catalogue of the Diptera of the Afrotropical Region</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Editor: R. W. Crosskey. Assistant editors: B. H. Cogan,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. Freeman, A. C. Pont, K. G. V. Smith and the late H. Oldroyd.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History). 1980, 1437 pp. 55.00</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Diptera or two-winged flies are probably the most important insects that affect man.<tei:lb/>Although most flies are harmless, some have become transmitters of dangerous diseases to<tei:lb/>man and his domestic animals, and others are important pests of agricultural crops. Some flies<tei:lb/>are beneficial because they destroy large numbers of plant-feeding insects through their<tei:lb/>parasitic or predacious habits.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nowhere is their socio-economic and medical impact more sharply felt than in tropical Africa,<tei:lb/>where fly-borne diseases are not only a direct health hazard but can prevent or hinder<tei:lb/>development of the land. The control of such diseases as sleeping sickness and onchocerciasis<tei:lb/>depends in great measure upon controlling the flies that carry them. This in turn requires a<tei:lb/>thorough appreciation of all that is known about the insect vectors, including their basic<tei:lb/>taxonomy, so that they can be correctly identified and their geographical ranges accurately<tei:lb/>established.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This catalogue synthesizes the scattered basic taxonomic work on the Diptera of tropical<tei:lb/>Africa and its islands by listing the known 16,500 species with their synonyms and known<tei:lb/>geographical ranges within a comprehensive classification. A short introduction is given to<tei:lb/>each family and a bibliography of 4,700 titles provides references to the primary literature.<tei:lb/>Such a task has never before been attempted for the region and its completion should greatly<tei:lb/>stimulate taxonomic research. The Catalogue represents ten years' careful work by a team of<tei:lb/>forty specialists, under the editorship of six dipterists on the staff of the Natural History<tei:lb/>Museum, themselves contributors with considerable expertise in the African fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Catalogue should serve for a long time as an indispensable tool to the taxonomist and an<tei:lb/>essential source-work to anyone concerned with African flies in the fields of medical,<tei:lb/>agricultural and veterinary science.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 50</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy of Neotropical Derbidae in the new tribe Mysidiini (Homoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By Peter S. Broomfield</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nymphal taxonomy and systematics of the Psylloidea (Homoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. M. White &amp; I. D. Hodkinson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The whitefly of New Guinea (Homoptera: Aleyrodidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By J.H.Martin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Photoset by Rowland Phototypesetting Ltd, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk<tei:lb/>Printed in Great Britain by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>
